{{Infobox organization | name = Aarhus Symposium | image = | purpose = "Leaders of today connecting with leaders of tomorrow"http://aarhus-symposium.org/about/ | founded = 2011 | founders = Kasper Vinther Olesen
Jens Riis Andersen
David Scherer
Andreas Emmertsen | board_of_directors = Michael Svarer
Jens Bjerg Sørensen
Peter Engberg Jensen
Nick Melgaard
Michael Jensen
Kristina Risom Jespersen
Kasper Vinther Olesen
Jens Riis Andersenhttp://aarhus-symposium.org/executive-board/ | type = Non-profit organisation | location = [[Aarhus University|University of Aarhus]], [[Aarhus]], [[Denmark]] | website = [http://www.aarhus-symposium.org aarhus-symposium.org] }} '''Aarhus Symposium''' is an annual leadership conference taking place at the [[Aarhus University|University of Aarhus]], [[Denmark]], on the first Friday in November. The aim of the event is to connect leaders of today with leaders of tomorrow. To do so, a wide range of key decision-makers are invited to share their experiences and engage in discussions with students from various universities. Hereby, the symposium allows students to relate their academic insights to the broader business society.http://studerende.au.dk/nyheder-og-arrangementer/nyhedsarkiv/nyhed/artikel/danske-topledere-ruster-au-studerende-til-barsk-virkelighed/ Aarhus Symposium was founded in 2011 and has since expanded its concept to also involve [[Aarhus Symposium#Aarhus Symposium Focus|Aarhus Symposium Focus]]http://www.netvaerksportalen.dk/artikler/studerende-og-topledere-moedes-i-faglig-debat-aarhus-symposium and [[Aarhus Symposium#Aarhus Symposium Challenge|Aarhus Symposium Challenge]].http://borsen.dk/nyheder/avisen/artikel/11/97854/artikel.html Aarhus Symposium is a non-profit organisation, and all symposia are organised by voluntary students together with a pro-bono board of directors.http://jyllands-posten.dk/aarhus/erhverv/ECE7183981/Leder-event-udsolgt-p%C3%A5-90-sekunder/http://aarhus-symposium.org/become-a-partner/ == History == Four students at [[Aarhus University]] established Aarhus Symposium in 2011: David Scherer, Jens Riis Andersen, Kasper Vinther Olesen, and Andreas Emmertsen. They gathered support from other students to organise the very first Aarhus Symposium with the objective of building a bridge between students, i.e. the future leaders, and leaders in today’s businesses and society.http://borsen.dk/nyheder/avisen/artikel/12/3184822/artikel.htmlhttp://stiften.dk/aarhus/Erhvervslivets-tunge-drenge-yder-studiehjaelp/artikel/92572 The first annual Aarhus Symposium welcomed renowned speakers from the business society such as Carsten Bjerg (then CEO of [[Grundfos]]), Lars Rohde (then CEO of [[Arbejdsmarkedets Tillægspension|ATP]]), and Maria Rønn (CEO of [[DR (broadcaster)|Danmarks Radio]]).http://aarhus-symposium.org/past-symposia/growth-in-distressed-economies/ Throughout the years, the programme has extended to include prominent speakers such as [[Frederik, Crown Prince of Denmark|His Royal Highness The Crown Prince of Denmark]],http://kongehuset.dk/menu/nyheder/abning-af-aarhus-symposium-2014 Lars Rebien Sørensen (president and CEO of [[Novo Nordisk]]),http://jyllands-posten.dk/aarhus/ECE8162162/Studerende-har-hyret-verdens-bedste-chef/ and the [[Denmark|Danish]] [[Prime minister|Prime Minister]] [[Lars Løkke Rasmussen]].https://jyskebank.tv/nutidens-og-fremtidens-ledere-modes-til-aarhus Aarhus Symposium has grown through the years as a result of wide support from students, speakers, partners, and others. In 2012, the Organising Committee introduced Battle of the Economists; an event to take place on Monday in the week of Aarhus Symposium. It provided a national focus to the overall theme of Aarhus Symposium.http://borsen.dk/nyheder/avisen/artikel/11/63904/artikel.html The event was renamed Aarhus Symposium Focus in 2016 to broaden the possibilities for topics that exceed economic issues.https://issuu.com/aarhussymposium/docs/booklet2016_final_rgb In 2013, Aarhus Symposium Challenge was established to strengthen the connection between students and the leaders of today. Aarhus Symposium Challenge is an essay competition in which selected speakers put forth a challenge for students to solve. Through their essay, students obtain a seat at both Aarhus Symposium and Aarhus Symposium Focus, and they potentially qualify for [[Aarhus Symposium#Leaders' Forum|Leaders’ Forum]]. Since its initiation in 2013, an increasing number of students have participated in Aarhus Symposium Challenge, making it the primary sign-up for Aarhus Symposium and Aarhus Symposium Focus.http://aarhus-symposium.org/aarhus-symposium-challenge/ == Aarhus Symposium == [[File:ASClimate.jpg|thumb|left|Climate Debate at Aarhus Symposium 2015 between (from left) Andreas Roepstorff, Connie Hedegaard, and Simon Giles moderated by Poul Erik Skammelsen.]] Aarhus Symposium takes place on the first Friday in November. Here, business executives and key decision-makers are invited to share their experiences and insights regarding a specific theme. They do so with different perspectives that reflect the tracks, i.e. subtopics, of the event. {{Clear}} === Past symposia === [[File:ASCrown.jpg|thumb|right|His Royal Highness The Crown Prince of Denmark’s opening speech at Aarhus Symposium 2014.]] {| class="wikitable collapsible" |- ! Christiansen]], CEO, [[The Lego Group]] * Afshan Khan, Regional Director, Europe & Central Asia, [[UNICEF]] * Ulrik Juul Christensen, Executive Chairman, Area9 Group * Rodin Genoff, Founder & Managing Director, Rodin Genoff and Associates * Søren Skou, CEO, [[Maersk Group]] * Jakob Askou Bøss, Senior VP, Corporate Strategy and Stakeholder Relations, [[Ørsted (company)|Ørsted]] * Christian Erfurt, CEO and Co-Founder, Be My Eyes * Michael Bruun, Partner and Managing Director, [[Goldman Sachs]] * Inge Berneke, Partner, [[Egon Zehnder]] * Lars Jannick Johansen, Founder & Managing Partner, The Social Capital Fond * Lene Skole, CEO, Lundbeckfonden |720 |} == Aarhus Symposium Focus == ''Formerly known as Battle of the Economists'' Aarhus Symposium Focus is an annual conference which takes place on Monday in the week of Aarhus Symposium. Here, experts with various backgrounds are invited to share their thoughts on a topic related to the overall theme of Aarhus Symposium. The event provides a national focus as the topic strives to reflect one of Denmark’s most critical challenges.http://borsen.dk/nyheder/opinion/artikel/1/334143/thomas_bernt_loekke-retraete_er_tredobbelt_lussing_til_virksomhederne.html [[File:ASFocus.jpg|thumb|right|Participants at Battle of the Economists 2015]] {| class="wikitable collapsible" |- ! Andersen, professor of economics at [[Aarhus University]] || 250 |- valign="top" ! 2013 | Denmark’s Challenges - Leadership and Innovation || *Peter Mogensen, CEO of Kraka *Philipp Schröder, professor of economics at [[Aarhus University]] *[[Martin Ågerup]], president at [[CEPOS]] || 400 |- valign="top" ! 2014 | The Superior Nordic Strategy || *Erik Bjørsted, chief analyst at AE-rådet *Otto Brøns-Petersen, head of research at [[CEPOS]] *Torben M. Andersen, professor of economics at [[Aarhus University]] || 400 |- valign="top" ! 2015 | Go Green, Now? || *Ditlev Engel, chairman of the board at Big Future 2025 *Michael Svarer, professor at the Department of Economics and Management, [[Aarhus University]] *Thomas Dalsgaard, executive vice president at [[DONG Energy]] Thermal Power || 450 |- valign="top" ! 2016 | Demographic Changes – How will we work, age, and live? || *Allan Lyngsø Madsen, chief economist at [[Danish Confederation of Trade Unions|LO]] *Torben Tranæs, executive director of Research at SFI *Troels Bjerg, regional CEO Northern Europe at [[ISS A/S]] || 375 |- valign="top" ! 2017 | Globalisation In Reverse – The Danish Response || *[[Christian Friis Bach]], former executive secretary at [United Nations Economic Commission for Europe|UNECE] *Dennis Novy, associate professor of economics at [[University of Warwick]] *Edward Ashbee, associate professor at Department of Business and Politics, [[Copenhagen Business School]] *Thomas Schulz, group CEO at [[FLSmidth]] || 375 |- valign="top" !2018 |Making Automation Work | * Lars Frelle-Petersen, Director of Digisation, Confederation of Danish Industry * Dominik Bösl, Vice President, Consumer Driven Robots, [[KUKA]] * Philipp Schröder, Member of the Danish Disruption Council * David Budtz-Petersen, Head of Research, Humanomics Research Center |400 |} == Aarhus Symposium Challenge == Aarhus Symposium Challenge is an essay competition where selected speakers put forth a challenge for students to solve. By submitting a qualified essay, students obtain a seat at both Aarhus Symposium and Aarhus Symposium Focus. Additionally, the participating students compete for the Aarhus Symposium Award and a spot in Leaders’ Forum. {| class="wikitable collapsible" |- ! Year ! Speakers and topics of Aarhus Symposium Challenge |- valign="top" ! 2013 | *Jim Hagemann Snabe, co-CEO at [[SAP SE|SAP AG]]: ''Facing global challenges with IT innovation'' *Nils S. Andersen, group CEO of [[Maersk|A.P. Moller-Mærsk A/S]]: ''Leading in troubled waters'' *Peter Beske Nielsen, managing director at Blackrock: ''Financial innovation'' |- valign="top" ! 2014 | *[[General officer|General]] [[Peter Bartram]], Danish Chief of Defence: ''Abilities of a modern leader'' *[[Peder Tuborgh]], CEO of [[Arla Foods]]: ''Communication strategy on a global stage'' *Thomas F. Borgen, group CEO of [[Danske Bank]]: ''Transformation through leadership'' |- valign="top" ! 2015 | *[[Christian Stadil]], CEO of Thornico: ''Ensuring the success of a startup'' *[[Connie Hedegaard]], chairman of the board at KR Foundation: ''Initiatives securing our future'' *Robert Uggla, CEO of [[Svitzer]]: ''Leader in the digital age'' |- valign="top" ! 2016 | *[[Jimmy Maymann]], president of [[AOL]] Content and Consumer Brands: ''The influence of digitalisation'' *[[Morten Albæk]], co-founder and CEO of Voluntas: ''Investing for impact'' *Peder Holk Nielsen, president and CEO of [[Novozymes]]: ''Partnering for success'' |- valign="top" ! 2017 | *[[Bjarne Corydon]], global director of McKinsey Center for Government: ''The challenge facing public institutions'' *Helle Valentin, global chief operating officer of Watson Internet of Things: ''How technology can create positive change'' *Janina Kugel, chief human resources officer and member of the managing board at [[Siemens]]: ''Successfully leading the employee of tomorrow'' |- valign="top" !2018 | * Niels B. Christiansen, CEO, [[The Lego Group]]: ''How a company can enjoy the advantages of collaborating with others wile protecting its core values'' * Afshan Khan, Regional Director Europe & Central Asia, [[UNICEF]]: ''One area in which every child does not have equal opportunities and one way to address this issue'' * Ulrik Juul Christensen, Founder and Executive Chairman, Area9 Group: ''How to achieve a specific competence that will be important on the future labour market'' |} === Leaders' Forum === [[File:ASForum.jpg|thumb|left|Leaders’ Forum session with Connie Hedegaard at Aarhus Symposium 2015.]] Leaders’ Forum is an exclusive and intimate session where selected students discuss their essay contribution with the leader that put forth the respective challenge. Only the best essay contributions under each challenge topic qualifies for this informal session.http://aarhus-symposium.org/challenge-faq/ Throughout the years, Leaders’ Forum has attracted much attention from the media inasmuch as it is unique in a Danish context and provides both the attending students and the top leaders the opportunity to learn from each other.http://borsen.dk/nyheder/avisen/artikel/11/97871/artikel.htmlhttp://www.business.dk/digital/jimmy-maymann-det-nytter-ikke-at-ville-holde-fremskridtet-tilbage {{Clear}} === The Aarhus Symposium Award === [[File:ASAward.jpg|thumb|right|Oskar Harmsen, winner of the Aarhus Symposium Award 2015, rewarded on stage at Aarhus Symposium 2015.]] The most extraordinary essay contribution in Aarhus Symposium Challenge will be rewarded the Aarhus Symposium Award on stage at the very end of Aarhus Symposium. Prior winners of the Aarhus Symposium Award are: *2013: Bastian Stemann Lauhttp://aarhus-symposium.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/AarhusSymposiumChallenge2013_WinnerPortrait.pdf *2014: Moma Vujisichttp://aarhus-symposium.org/2014/12/02/meet-the-winner-of-the-aarhus-symposium-award-2014/ *2015: Oskar Harmsenhttp://aarhus-symposium.org/2015/12/18/meet-the-winner-of-the-aarhus-symposium-award-2015/ *2016: Luke McGintyhttp://aarhus-symposium.org/2017/03/26/interview-luke-mcginty-winner-aarhus-symposium-award-2016/ *2017: Bastian Emil Jørgensenhttp://aarhus-symposium.org/2017/11/03/bastian-emil-jorgensen-winner-of-the-aarhus-symposium-award-2017/ *2018: Soraya Redondo Mezmizi {{Clear}} == Other events == Besides facilitating Aarhus Symposium and Aarhus Symposium Focus, Aarhus Symposium also hosts a variety of other events that takes places at Aarhus University. Most notable are Aarhus Symposium Theme Announcement and Aarhus Symposium Challenge Launch; both of which are closely linked to the three key elements of Aarhus Symposium.http://aarhus-symposium.org/news/http://omnibus.au.dk/en/archive/show/artikel/morgendagens-leder-er-det-dig/ == Organising Committee == The Organising Committee of Aarhus Symposium consists of approximately 35 voluntary students,http://aarhus-symposium.org/organisers/ who have the responsibility for planning, funding, promoting, and executing all events.http://bss.au.dk/om-aarhus-bss/nyheder/vis/artikel/hvordan-saetter-man-store-erhvervsledere-i-staevne/ The Organising Committee is divided into smaller groups with specific focus areas:http://aarhus-symposium.org/organisers/the-groups-of-aarhus-symposium/ *Steering Committee *Programme Group *Business Relations Group *Marketing Group *Essentials Group *University Alliances *IT Group *Finance Group == External links == *Website: [http://www.aarhus-symposium.org aarhus-symposium.org] *Aarhus Symposium: [http://www.aarhus-symposium.org/aarhus-symposium aarhus-symposium.org/aarhus-symposium] *Aarhus Symposium Focus: [http://www.aarhus-symposium.org/aarhus-symposium-focus aarhus-symposium.org/aarhus-symposium-focus] *Aarhus Symposium Challenge: [http://www.aarhus-symposium.org/aarhus-symposium-challenge/ aarhus-symposium.org/aarhus-symposium-challenge/] == References == {{reflist|2}} [[Category:Events in Denmark]] [[Category:Organized events]] [[Category:Aarhus University]] [[Category:Student events]] [[Category:Conferences]] [[Category:Academic conferences]] [[Category:Organizations based in Aarhus]] [[Category:Student organizations in Denmark]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Denmark]] [[Category:Business conferences]] [[Category:Autumn events in Denmark]]

{{other uses}} {{redirect|Misadventure}} {{refimprove|date=August 2010}} [[Image:Partial stadium collapse at Big12 college football championship - 2005.JPG|right|thumb|A [[Guard rail|railing]] accident at a [[Texas Longhorns]] [[college football]] game, spilling [[fan (aficionado)|fans]] onto the sidelines]]
An '''accident''', also known as an '''unintentional injury''', is an undesirable, incidental, and an unplanned event that could have been prevented had [[Attendant circumstance|circumstances]] leading up to the accident been recognized, and acted upon, prior to its occurrence. Most scientists who study unintentional injury avoid using the term "accident" and focus on factors that increase risk of severe injury and that reduce injury incidence and severity.<ref name=Robertson2015>{{cite book | last = Robertson | first = Leon S. | title = Injury Epidemiology: Fourth Edition | year = 2015 | publisher = Lulu Books | url = http://www.nanlee.net/}}</ref>
==Types== [[File:Unintentional injuries world map-Deaths per million persons-WHO2012.svg|thumb|Unintentional injury deaths per million persons in 2012 {{refbegin|2}}{{legend|#ffff20|107-247}}{{legend|#ffe820|248-287}}{{legend|#ffd820|288-338}}{{legend|#ffc020|339-387}}{{legend|#ffa020|388-436}}{{legend|#ff9a20|437-505}}{{legend|#f08015|506-574}}{{legend|#e06815|575-655}}{{legend|#d85010|656-834}}{{legend|#d02010|835-1,165}}{{refend}} ]]
===Physical and non-physical=== Physical examples of accidents include unintended motor vehicle collisions or falls, being injured by touching something sharp, hot, moving objects, contacting electricity or ingesting poison. Non-physical examples are unintentionally revealing a [[secret]] or otherwise saying something incorrectly, accidental deletion of data, forgetting an appointment etc.
===By activity=== * Accidents during the execution of work or arising out of it are called [[work accident]]s. According to the International Labour Organization (ILO), more than 337 million accidents happen on the job each year, resulting, together with occupational diseases, in more than 2.3 million deaths annually.<ref>"[http://www.ilo.org/global/topics/safety-and-health-at-work/lang--en/index.htm ILO Safety and Health at Work]". International Labour Organization (ILO)</ref> * In contrast, [[leisure]]-related accidents are mainly [[Sports injury|sports injuries]].
===By vehicle=== [[File:A. Provost - Versailles - Railroad Disaster.jpg|thumb|[[Versailles rail accident]] in 1842]] * [[Aviation accidents and incidents|Aviation]] * [[Bicycle safety|Bicycles]] * [[Sailing ships]] * [[Traffic collision]]s * [[Train wrecks]] * [[Trams]]
==Common causes== {{See also|Preventable causes of death}} [[File:Accidents.svg|thumb|300px|Incidence of accidents (of a severity of resulting in seeking medical care), sorted by activity (in Denmark in 2002).]] Poisons, vehicle collisions and falls are the most common causes of fatal injuries. According to a 2005 survey of injuries sustained at home, which used data from the National Vital Statistics System of the United States [[National Center for Health Statistics]], falls, poisoning, and fire/burn injuries are the most common causes of death.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Runyan CW, Casteel C, Perkis D |title=Unintentional injuries in the home in the United States Part I: mortality |journal=Am J Prev Med |volume=28 |issue=1 |pages=73–9 |date=January 2005 |pmid=15626560 |doi=10.1016/j.amepre.2004.09.010 |url=|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
The United States also collects statistically valid injury data (sampled from 100 hospitals) through the National Electronic Injury Surveillance System administered by the [[Consumer Product Safety Commission]].<ref name=NEISS>CPSC. [http://www.cpsc.gov/en/Safety-Education/Safety-Guides/General-Information/National-Electronic-Injury-Surveillance-System-NEISS/ National Electronic Injury Surveillance System (NEISS)]. Database query available through: [http://www.cpsc.gov/en/Research--Statistics/NEISS-Injury-Data/ NEISS Injury Data].</ref> This program was revised in 2000 to include all injuries rather than just injuries involving products.<ref name=NEISS/> Data on [[emergency department]] visits is also collected through the [[National Health Interview Survey]].<ref>NCHS. [https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/fastats/ervisits.htm Emergency Department Visits]. CDC.</ref> In The U.S. the [[Bureau of Labor Statistics]] has available on their website extensive statistics on workplace accidents.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bls.gov/iif|title=Injuries, Illnesses, and Fatalities|author=|date=|website=www.bls.gov}}</ref>
==Accident models==
Many models to characterize and analyze accidents have been proposed,<ref>A long list of books and papers is given in: {{cite book|title=Enhancing Occupational Safety and Health|date=2004|author=Taylor, G.A.|author2=Easter, K.M.|author3=Hegney, R.P.|publisher=Elsevier|isbn=0750661976|pages=241–245, see also pages 140–141 and pages 147–153, also on Kindle}}</ref> which can by classified by type. Notable types and models include:<ref>{{cite book |url=http://www.ohsbok.org.au/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/32-Models-of-causation-Safety.pdf |title=OHS Body of Knowledge |author1=Yvonne Toft |author2=Geoff Dell |author3=Karen K Klockner |author4=Allison Hutton |chapter=Models of Causation: Safety|editor= HaSPA (Health and Safety Professionals Alliance) |publisher=Safety Institute of Australia Ltd. |date=April 2012 |isbn=978-0-9808743-1-0}}</ref> * Sequential models ** Domino Theory<ref>{{cite book |author=H.W. Heinreich |year=1931 |title=Industrial Accident Prevention |publisher=McGraw-Hill}}</ref> ** Loss Causation Model<ref>Bird and Germain, 1985</ref> * Complex linear models ** Energy Damage Model<ref>Gibson, Haddon, Viner</ref> ** Time sequence models *** Generalized Time Sequence Model<ref>Viner</ref> *** Accident Evolution and Barrier Function<ref>Svenson</ref> ** Epidemiological models *** Gordon 1949 *** Onward Mappings Model based on Resident Pathogens Metaphor<ref>{{cite book |chapter=Too Little and Too Late: A Commentary on Accident and Incident Reporting |last=Reason |first=James T. |year=1991 |pages=9–26 |title=Near Miss Reporting as a Safety Tool |publisher=Butterworth-Heinemann |editor1-last=Van Der Schaaf |editor1-first=T.W. |editor2-last=Lucas |editor2-first=D.A. |editor3-last=Hale |editor3-first=A.R.}}</ref> * Process model ** Benner 1975 * Systemic models ** Rasmussen ** Reason Model of System Safety (embedding the [[Swiss cheese model]]) *** [[Healthcare error proliferation model]] *** [[Human reliability]] ** Woods, 1994 * Non-linear models ** [[System accident]]<ref>Perrow, 1984</ref> ** Systems-Theoretic Accident Model and Process (STAMP)<ref>Leveson 2004</ref> ** Functional Resonance Accident Model (FRAM) <ref>Hollnagel, 2004</ref> ** Assertions that all existing models are insufficient<ref>Dekker 2011</ref>
[[Ishikawa diagram]]s are sometimes used to illustrate [[root-cause analysis]] and [[five whys]] discussions.
== See also ==
===General=== * [[Accident analysis]] ** [[Root cause analysis]] * [[Accident-proneness]] * [[Idiot-proof]] * [[Injury]] * [[Injury prevention]] * [[List of accidents and disasters by death toll]] * [[Safety]] * [[Safety engineering]] ** [[Fail-safe]] ** [[Poka-yoke]] * [[Risk management]]
===Transportation=== * [[Air safety]] ** [[Aviation accidents and incidents]] * [[Bicycle safety]] * Car ** [[Automobile safety]] ** [[Traffic collision]] * [[List of rail accidents]] * [[Tram accident]] * [[Sailing ship accidents]]
===Other specific topics=== * [[Aisle#Safety and regulatory considerations|Aisles: Safety and regulatory considerations]] * [[Explosives safety]] * [[Nuclear and radiation accidents]] * [[Occupational safety and health]] ** [[Safety data sheet]] ** [[Personal protective equipment]] ** [[Criticality accident]] * [[Sports injury]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} '''Accidental incest''' is [[Human sexual activity|sexual activity]] or [[marriage]] between persons who were unaware of a family relationship between them which would be considered [[incest]]uous.
The laws of many jurisdictions [[Void marriage|void incestuous marriages]], even if entered into without awareness of the kinship. If an incestuous relationship is suspected, [[DNA testing]] may be used. Some jurisdictions permit offspring of IVF donations access to donation records or to adoption records.
==Causes== People may be unaware of a [[kinship]] relationship between them in a number of circumstances. For example, [[artificial insemination]] with an anonymous [[sperm donation|donated sperm]] may result in offspring being unaware of any biological relations, such as paternity or half siblings. To reduce the likelihood of accidental incest, fertility clinics usually limit the number of times that a donor's sperm may be used.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=9iJlAAAAIBAJ&sjid=RYgNAAAAIBAJ&pg=2368,2279497&dq=accidental-incest |title=Accidental Incest Risk Increases |date=15 March 1979 |work=Edmonton Journal |agency=Associated Press |page=61 |accessdate=23 March 2011 |location=Boston}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=coNSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hwUEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6125,3788930&dq=accidental-incest |title=Report From A Test Tube Baby |last=Atallah |first=Lillian |date=19 April 1976 |work=Ocala Star-Banner |page=35 |accessdate=23 March 2011}}</ref> Some countries have laws limiting the number of children a donor can father.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/09/30/international/europe/30sperm.html |title=Spreading Scandinavian Genes, Without Viking Boats |last=Alvarez |first=Lizette |date=30 September 2004 |work=The New York Times |accessdate=23 March 2011}}</ref> while others limit sperm donations based on family numbers to enable one family to have true siblings.
[[Taiwan]] allows those conceived by artificial means to find out if they are related to a person they are considering marrying.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2007/05/11/2003360370 |title=DOH working on provision to stop accidental incest |last=Oung |first=Angelica |date=11 May 2007 |work=The Taipei Times |page=2 |accessdate=23 March 2011 |location=Taiwan}}</ref>
Accidental incest may also arise in the following situations: * Children separated from their family at birth, * [[Child abandonment]],<ref>{{cite book |last=Angelica |first=Jade Christine |title=A Moral Emergency: Breaking the Cycle of Child Sexual Abuse |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-F92TlEyr8oC&pg=PA59&dq=%22accidental+incest%22&ei=-P-HTa2tOKqO0QHR58T9DQ&resnum=2&ved=0CC0Q6AEwATgK&q=%22accidental%20incest%22 |page=59}}</ref> * Sexual exploration.
==Notable cases== *In 2008, it was reported that a British brother and sister, who were twins separated at birth, married without knowing of their relationship. According to the report, the relationship was discovered soon after their wedding, and the marriage was annulled. The case has raised the issue regarding whether adoptions should be kept secret.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/europe/01/11/twins.married/?imw=Y&iref=mpstoryemail |title=Unknowing twins married, lawmaker says |publisher=CNN |accessdate=23 March 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://culturekitchen.com/mole333/blog/accidental_incest_twins_separated_at_birth_marr |title=Accidental Incest: Twins Separated at Birth Marry |last=Sabater |first=Liza |publisher=Culture Kitchen |accessdate=23 March 2011}}</ref> Concerns have been raised, however, about whether the story is, in fact, true.<ref>{{cite news |first=Jon |last=Henley |url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2008/jan/15/familyandrelationships.jonhenley |title=Did a pair of twins really get married by mistake? |work=The Guardian |accessdate=3 April 2012 |location=London |date=15 January 2008}}</ref> *An engaged couple in South Africa, who had been together for five years and were expecting a child, discovered that they were brother and sister just before their wedding. They were raised separately and met as adults in college. Just before the wedding, their parents met and they came to realize that they were siblings. The couple broke off the relationship after the discovery.<ref>{{cite news |first=Stewart |last=Maclean |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2057081/Engaged-couple-discover-brother-sister-parents-meet-days-wedding.html |title=Engaged couple discover they are brother and sister when their parents meet just before wedding |newspaper=[[Daily Mail]] |date=3 November 2011 |accessdate=9 November 2011}}</ref>
==See also== *''[[Oedipus Rex]]'' *[[Mordred]] *[[Andorra (play)|''Andorra'' (play)]] *[[Yrsa]]

{{Multiple issues| {{COI|date=March 2011}} {{BLP sources|date=March 2011}} {{autobiography|date=April 2011}} }}
{{Infobox person | name =Andrea Elizabeth Michaels | image = Andrea Accepting AwardCropped3.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Andrea Michaels at the Special Event Convention in 2005. | birth_name = Andrea Elizabeth Gerson | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1943|12|14}} | birth_place = [[Rab]], Croatia | residence = | nationality = | other_names = | ethnicity = | education = | alma_mater = [[University of California at Los Angeles]] | occupation = Event producer, business owner, author and speaker | organization = Extraordinary Events | known_for = | notable_works = | net_worth = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | website = {{URL|www.extraordinaryevents.net}} | footnotes = }} '''Andrea Elizabeth Michaels''' (née Gerson; born December 14, 1943) is an American meeting and event producer, author and speaker.<ref name=Stepping>Wright, David, ''Stepping Stones to Success - Experts Share Strategies for Mastering Business, Life and Relationships - with Deepak Chopra, Jack Canfield, Andrea Michaels and Dr. Denis Waitley''. Sevierville, Tennessee: Insight Publishing, 2010, pp. 237-248.</ref> As founder of an international event production company, Extraordinary Events, Michaels and her company produce large corporate events. She is an original member of the special events industry Hall of Fame<ref>Baragona, Carolyn, "Spotlight Award/Hall of Fame Inductees," ''Event Solutions'' magazine, December, 2002.</ref> and the author of a business biography,<ref name=reflect>>Michaels, Andrea, ''Reflections of a Successful Wallflower - Lessons in Business; Lessons in Life.'' Denver: Outskirts Press, 2010.</ref> and is featured in three [[anthologies]].
== Early life == Andrea Michaels was born in the [[Arbe concentration camp]] (today [[Rab]], [[Croatia]], on the northern shore of the [[Adriatic Sea]]) to Lelja Kauders (b. Zagreb, Yugoslavia, August 25, 1923 – d. Los Angeles California, May 30, 2009).<ref>Tributes.com/show/Lelja-Gerson</ref><ref name=ben7879>Wright, David, ''Yes You Can! Reaching Your Potential While Achieving Greatness - with Dr. Warren Bennis, Andrea Michaels and Jim Rohn''. Sevierville, Tennessee: Insight Publishing, 2010, pp. 77-88.</ref> Michaels and her mother, along with her mother's [[Jewish]] parents, Paul (Palvo) Kauders and Elza Ackerman Kauders, escaped in a small boat across the Adriatic to Italy.<ref name="ben7879"/> Michaels lived in Italy to the age of four with her grandparents until her mother, who had married an American pilot, sent for her to come live in America.<ref name="ben7879"/> The marriage ended, and after Michaels arrived in America, her mother married Peter Gerson, who adopted Andrea and moved the family from [[Silverlake, California]], to [[Hollywood]].<ref name="ben7879"/> When Michaels was ten, the family moved to [[Burbank, California]].<ref name="ben7879"/>
An only child Michaels graduated from [[Burbank High School (Burbank, California)|Burbank High School]] in 1961.<ref>http://www.classmates.com/places/school/school/3516/m?startYear=1900&endYear=9999&communityId=3516</ref> Michaels attended the [[University of California at Berkeley]] in 1961 and 1962, transferring to the [[University of California at Los Angeles]] (UCLA) before marrying Bob Spritz on February 1, 1964.<ref name="ben7879"/> The marriage lasted ten years, and they had a son, Jon (b. July 24, 1970).<ref name=reflect/> After her divorce from Spritz, she changed her last name as well as that of her son's to "Michaels."<ref name=reflect/> Michaels returned to UCLA in 1970 and earned a degree, with honors, in [[Psychology]].<ref>2002 Hall of Fame, NAWBOLA.org./About_Us/2002_hof.php</ref>
== Early career == Instead of pursuing a career in Psychology, Michaels began working with the Ron Rubin Orchestras in 1973.<ref>Barnett, Maggie, "Spectacular Events Keep Encino Firm in Demand," Features Section, Los Angeles Times, November 23, 1999.</ref> During that time, she became interested in the [[event planning]] business when there was no formalized industry. She produced her first event in 1978—-a [[Anniversary|bicentennial]] celebration for Marsh McClellan Insurance Company. By 1982, the company had been restructured and renamed Michaels, Rubin and Associates.<ref name=ben7879 /> Michaels and Rubin dissolved their relationship in December 1988, and on that same day, Extraordinary Events was launched.<ref>"Coffee With Andrea Michaels - Meetings And Conventions". Meetings-conventions.com. 2010-08-01. http://www.meetings-conventions.com/articles/coffee-with-andrea-michaels/a35650.aspx. Retrieved 2011-02-09.</ref><ref>Barnett, Maggie, "Spectacular Events Keep Encino Firm in Demand," Features Section, ''Los Angeles Times'', November 23, 1999. Found online as an abstract at [https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/46600664.html?dids=46600664:46600664&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Nov+23%2C+1999&author=MAGGIE+BARNETT&pub=Los+Angeles+Times&desc=VALLEY+BUSINESS+%2F+ADVANCING+WOMEN%3A+PROFILES+OF+SUCCESS%3B+Spectacular+Events+Keep+Encino+Firm+in+Demand%3B+Entertainment%3A+Staging+big+productions+for+major+companies+is+a+hectic+but+profitable+venture+for+one+Valley+entrepreneur.&pqatl=google Los Angeles Times archives]. Accessed March 17, 2011.</ref> At that time, Michaels began to bring to the corporate world the spectaculars that had been produced on football fields, Disneyland and in entertainment venues<ref name=Stepping /> by the late [[Tommy Walker (events director)|Tommy Walker]] and the late [[Robert (Bob) Jani]].
== Later career == Extraordinary Events has specialized in planning and producing corporate events globally including Europe, Asia, Canada, Mexico, the Caribbean, Africa, Australia and New Zealand.<ref name=ben7879 /> In 2006, ''Special Events'' magazine listed Extraordinary Events as one of the "Top 50 Event Planning Companies."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eddiedeensranch.com/press/5th_annual_50_top_event_plan.pdf|title=www.eddiedeensranch.com/press/5th_annual_50_top_event_plan.pdf<!--INSERT TITLE-->|format=PDF}}</ref><ref>Hurley, Lisa, "5th Annual 50 Top Event Planning Companies List," ''Special Events'' magazine, September 12, 2006, pages 45-50.</ref> The [[Los Angeles Business Journal]] named it Number 28 on its list of the "Fastest Growing Private Companies"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.northstarmobilestorage.com/pdf/awards/2006.50_Fastest_Growing_Companies_SFVBJ.pdf|title=www.northstarmobilestorage.com/pdf/awards/2006.50_Fastest_Growing_Companies_SFVBJ.pdf<!--INSERT TITLE-->|format=PDF|access-date=2011-02-01|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101117054629/http://www.northstarmobilestorage.com/pdf/awards/2006.50_Fastest_Growing_Companies_SFVBJ.pdf|archive-date=2010-11-17|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> in 2006, jumping from Number 80<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.goetzmangroup.com/uploads/pdf/FastestGrowing1-100.pdf |title=DataJoe |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2011-02-09 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090107040008/http://www.goetzmangroup.com/uploads/pdf/FastestGrowing1-100.pdf |archive-date=2009-01-07 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> in 2005 and then to Number 48<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.altour.com/PressClipsDynamic%5Chttp___content.burrellesluce.com_cgi-bin_show_article.pl_go=show_article&show=pdf&type=existing&article_id=NewsExpress%20Women-Owned%20Businesses.pdf|title=DataJoe |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2011-02-09}}</ref> in 2005 and then to Number 48<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.altour.com/PressClipsDynamic%5Chttp___content.burrellesluce.com_cgi-bin_show_article.pl_go=show_article&show=pdf&type=existing&article_id=NewsExpress%20Women-Owned%20Businesses.pdf|title=Women-owned Michaels and her company began to incorporate charitable activities into its events with the rebuilding of an elementary school in Leona Vicario, Mexico, with client CEMEX, a concrete manufacturer, in 2005. The ''Los Angeles Business Journal''<ref name=labj>{{citation |url = http://www.aooevents.com/press/LABusinessJournal_Jan07.pdf |format = PDF |accessdate = 2011-02-09 |title = Event Heaven |author = Emily Bryson York |date = 8 January 2007 |publisher = Los Angeles Business Journal |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110707151622/http://www.aooevents.com/press/LABusinessJournal_Jan07.pdf |archive-date = 2011-07-07 |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref> and ''Financial and Insurance Meetings '' magazine<ref>{{cite web|author =Lisa Hurley |url=http://meetingsnet.com/0401-giving-back-teambuilding/ |title=Do-Good Events | Today's teambuilding events are about giving back |publisher=Meetingsnet.com |date=2009-04-01 |accessdate=2011-02-09}}</ref> covered the event.
Michaels and Extraordinary Events have won the following awards: * 34 ''Special Events'' magazine Gala Awards<ref name=Bushido>Wright, David, ''Bushido Business - The Fine Art of the Modern Professional - with Tom Hopkins, Andrea Michaels, Brian Tracy and Stephen M.R. Covey. Sevierville, Tennessee: Insight Publishing, 2010, pp. 65-76.</ref> * 2 ''Special Events'' magazine Gala Awards of Excellence<ref name=Stepping /> * 2 WOW Awards<ref name=Bushido /> * 1 Meeting Planners International Paragon Award<ref name=event>{{cite web|url=http://www.event-solutions.com/andrea_michaels |title=Andrea Michaels |publisher=Event Solutions |date= |accessdate=2011-02-09}}</ref> * 2 Society of Incentive and Travel Executives Crystal Awards<ref name=Bushido /><ref>{{cite web|editor = Barbara Scofidio |url=http://meetingsnet.com/corporatemeetingsincentives/incentives/role_models/meetings_toast_010107/ |title=winners of SITE's Crystal Awards |publisher=Meetingsnet.com |date=2007-01-01 |accessdate=2011-02-09}}</ref> * 3 EIBTM Awards<ref name=Bushido/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.conworld.net/index.php/Europe/only-1-week-left-to-enter-prestigious-meetings-and-incentive-industry-awards.html |title=Only 1 Week left to enter prestigious Meetings and Incentive Industry Awards |publisher=Conworld.net |date=2009-09-08 |accessdate=2011-02-09| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101226110957/http://www.conworld.net/index.php/Europe/only-1-week-left-to-enter-prestigious-meetings-and-incentive-industry-awards.html| archivedate= 26 December 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> * 1 ''Successful Meetings'' Super Six Award<ref>"And the Winners Are...2004-12-01," ''Successful Meetings'', December 1, 2004.</ref> * National Association for Women in Business Hall of Fame 2002<ref name=nawb>{{cite web |url=http://www.nawbola.org/about_us/2002_hof.php |title=2002 Hall of Fame |publisher=Nawbola.org |date= |accessdate=2011-02-09 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110410221531/http://www.nawbola.org/about_us/2002_hof.php |archive-date=2011-04-10 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> * ''Event Solutions'' Magazine Hall of Fame 2002<ref name=event/><ref>Baragona, Carolyn, "Spotlight Awards/Hall of Fame Inductees," ''Event Solutions'', December, 2002.</ref>

R. Covey.

In 2007, Michaels developed a mentor program<ref>{{cite web|author =CHRISTINE LANDRY |url=http://specialevents.com/mag/events_masters_class_2070318/ |title=Event expert Andrea Michaels plans mentor program |publisher=Specialevents.com |date=2007-03-01 |accessdate=2011-02-09}}</ref> to offer an in-the-field special event education and international exchange program to assist event newcomers. Michaels is currently a faculty member at California State University, Long Beach College of Continuing and Professional Education<ref>http://www.ccpe.csulb.edu</ref> and teaches [[event management]].

{{short description|Toxic effects of carbon monoxide }} {{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = Carbon monoxide poisoning | synonyms = Carbon monoxide intoxication, carbon monoxide toxicity, carbon monoxide overdose | image = Carbon-monoxide-3D-balls.png | alt = A carbon atom (shown as a grey ball) tripled bonded to an oxygen atom (shown as a red ball). | caption = [[Carbon monoxide]] | field = [[Toxicology]], [[emergency medicine]] | symptoms = [[Headache]], [[dizziness]], weakness, vomiting, [[chest pain]], [[confusion]] | complications = [[Loss of consciousness]], [[arrhythmias]], [[seizures]] | onset = | duration = | types = | causes = [[inhalation|Breathing]] in [[carbon monoxide]] | risks = | diagnosis = [[Carboxyl-hemoglobin]] level:
3% (nonsmokers),
10% (smokers) | differential = [[Cyanide toxicity]], [[alcoholic ketoacidosis]], [[aspirin poisoning]], [[upper respiratory tract infection]]{{cite book|last1=Caterino|first1=Jeffrey M.|last2=Kahan|first2=Scott|title=In a Page: Emergency medicine|date=2003|publisher=Lippincott Williams & Wilkins|isbn=978-1405103572|page=309|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=O0LwFPZDKbsC&pg=PA309|accessdate=2 July 2017|language=en}} | prevention = [[Carbon monoxide detector]]s, venting of [[gas appliances]], maintenance of [[exhaust system]]s | treatment = [[Supportive care]], [[Oxygen therapy|100% oxygen]], [[hyperbaric oxygen therapy]] | medication = | prognosis = Risk of death 1 to 30%. | frequency = >20,000 emergency visits for non-fire related cases per year (US) | deaths = >400 non-fire related a year (US) }} '''Carbon monoxide poisoning''' typically occurs from [[inhalation|breathing]] in [[carbon monoxide]] (CO) at excessive levels.{{cite book|last1=Schottke|first1=David|title=Emergency Medical Responder: Your First Response in Emergency Care|date=2016|publisher=Jones & Bartlett Learning|isbn=978-1284107272|page=224|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gGCHDQAAQBAJ&pg=PA224|accessdate=2 July 2017|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170910171934/https://books.google.com/books?id=gGCHDQAAQBAJ&pg=PA224|archivedate=10 September 2017|df=}} Symptoms are often described as "[[flu]]-like" and commonly include [[headache]], [[dizziness]], weakness, vomiting, [[chest pain]], and [[confusion]]. Large exposures can result in [[loss of consciousness]], [[arrhythmias]], [[seizures]], or death. The classically described "cherry red skin" rarely occurs. Long term complications may include feeling tired, trouble with memory, and movement problems. In those [[smoke inhalation|exposed to smoke]], [[cyanide toxicity]] should also be considered.{{cite journal|last1=Guzman|first1=JA|title=Carbon monoxide poisoning.|journal=Critical care clinics|date=October 2012|volume=28|issue=4|pages=537–48|pmid=22998990|doi=10.1016/j.ccc.2012.07.007}} Carbon monoxide poisoning can occur accidentally or as an [[suicide|attempt to end one's life]]. CO is a colorless and odorless gas which is initially non-irritating.{{cite journal|last1=Bleecker|first1=ML|title=Carbon monoxide intoxication|journal=Handbook of clinical neurology|date=2015|volume=131|pages=191–203|pmid=26563790|doi=10.1016/B978-0-444-62627-1.00024-X|series=Handbook of Clinical Neurology|isbn=978-0444626271}} It is produced during [[incomplete combustion|incomplete burning]] of [[organic matter]]. This can occur from [[motor vehicles]], heaters, or cooking equipment that run on [[carbon-based fuel]]s. It can also occur from exposure to [[methylene chloride]]. Carbon monoxide primarily causes adverse effects by combining with [[hemoglobin]] to form [[carboxyhemoglobin]] (HbCO) preventing the [[blood]] from carrying [[oxygen]]. Additionally, [[myoglobin]] and [[mitochondria]]l [[cytochrome oxidase]] are affected. Diagnosis is based on a HbCO level of more than 3% among nonsmokers and more than 10% among smokers. Efforts to prevent poisoning include [[carbon monoxide detector]]s, proper venting of [[gas appliances]], keeping chimneys clean, and keeping [[exhaust system]]s of vehicles in good repair.{{cite web|last1=Health|first1=National Center for Environmental|title=Carbon Monoxide Poisoning – Frequently Asked Questions|url=https://www.cdc.gov/co/faqs.htm|website=www.cdc.gov|accessdate=2 July 2017|language=en-us|date=30 December 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170705012403/https://www.cdc.gov/co/faqs.htm|archivedate=5 July 2017|df=}} Treatment of poisoning generally consists of giving [[oxygen therapy|100% oxygen]] along with [[supportive care]]. This should generally be carried out until symptoms are no longer present and the HbCO level is less than 10%. While [[hyperbaric oxygen therapy]] is used for severe poisonings, the benefit over standard oxygen delivery is unclear.{{cite journal|last1=Buckley|first1=NA|last2=Juurlink|first2=DN|last3=Isbister|first3=G|last4=Bennett|first4=MH|last5=Lavonas|first5=EJ|title=Hyperbaric oxygen for carbon monoxide poisoning.|journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|date=13 April 2011|issue=4|pages=CD002041|pmid=21491385|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD002041.pub3}} The risk of death among those affected is between 1 and 30%. Carbon monoxide poisoning is relatively common, resulting in more than 20,000 [[emergency department]] visits a year in the United States.{{cite book|last1=Penney|first1=David G.|title=Carbon Monoxide Poisoning|date=2007|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=978-0849384189|page=569|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=793KBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA569|accessdate=2 July 2017|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170910171934/https://books.google.com/books?id=793KBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA569|archivedate=10 September 2017|df=}} It is the most common type of fatal poisoning in many countries.{{cite journal | author=Omaye ST | title=Metabolic modulation of carbon monoxide toxicity | journal=Toxicology |date=Nov 2002 | pages=139–50 | volume=180 | issue=2 | pmid=12324190 | doi=10.1016/S0300-483X(02)00387-6 }} In the United States non-fire related cases results in more than 400 deaths a year. Poisonings occur more often in the winter, particularly from the use of [[portable generators]] during [[power outage]]s.{{cite book|last1=Ferri|first1=Fred F.|title=Ferri's Clinical Advisor 2017 E-Book: 5 Books in 1|date=2016|publisher=Elsevier Health Sciences|isbn=978-0323448383|pages=227–28|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rRhCDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA227|accessdate=2 July 2017|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170910171934/https://books.google.com/books?id=rRhCDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA227|archivedate=10 September 2017|df=}} The toxic effects of CO have been known since [[ancient history]].{{cite journal|last1=Blumenthal|first1=I|title=Carbon monoxide poisoning.|journal=Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine|date=June 2001|volume=94|issue=6|pages=270–72|pmid=11387414|doi=10.1177/014107680109400604|pmc=1281520}} The realization that hemoglobin was affected by CO was determined in 1857. == Signs and symptoms == Carbon monoxide is not toxic to all forms of life. Its harmful effects are due to binding with hemoglobin so its danger to organisms that do not use this compound is doubtful. It thus has no effect on photosynthesising plants.{{cite web|url=http://ces.iisc.ernet.in/energy/HC270799/HDL/ENV/enven/vol321.htm|title=Carbon monoxide|work=ernet.in|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140414051805/http://ces.iisc.ernet.in/energy/HC270799/HDL/ENV/enven/vol321.htm|archivedate=2014-04-14|df=}} It is easily absorbed through the lungs. Inhaling the gas can lead to [[Cerebral hypoxia|hypoxic injury]], [[Brain damage|nervous system damage]], and even [[death]]. Different people and populations may have different carbon monoxide tolerance levels.{{cite journal|vauthors=Raub JA, Mathieu-Nolf M, Hampson NB, Thom SR |title=Carbon monoxide poisoning-a public health perspective|journal=Toxicology|date=April 2000|pages=1–14|volume=145|issue=1|pmid=10771127|doi=10.1016/S0300-483X(99)00217-6|subscription=yes}} On average, exposures at 100 [[parts per million|ppm]] or greater is dangerous to human health. In the [[United States]], the [[Occupational Safety and Health Administration|OSHA]] limits long-term workplace exposure levels to less than 50 ppm averaged over an 8-hour period;{{cite web|url=https://www.osha.gov/OshDoc/data_General_Facts/carbonmonoxide-factsheet.pdf|title=OSHA Fact Sheet: Carbon Monoxide|accessdate=2009-09-14|publisher=United States National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090826181843/http://osha.gov/OshDoc/data_General_Facts/carbonmonoxide-factsheet.pdf|archivedate=2009-08-26|df=}} in addition, employees are to be removed from any [[confined space]] if an upper limit ("ceiling") of 100 ppm is reached.{{cite web |url=https://www.osha.gov/pls/oshaweb/owadisp.show_document?p_table=STANDARDS&p_id=10366 |title=Carbon monoxide – 29 CFR Part 1917 Section 1917.24 |accessdate=2013-05-27 |publisher=United States Department of Labor: Occupational Safety and Health Administration |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130523211713/http://www.osha.gov/pls/oshaweb/owadisp.show_document?p_table=STANDARDS&p_id=10366 |archivedate=2013-05-23 |df= }} Carbon monoxide exposure may lead to a significantly shorter [[life expectancy|life span]] due to [[heart]] damage.{{cite journal|vauthors=Henry CR, Satran D, Lindgren B, Adkinson C, Nicholson CI, Henry TD |title= Myocardial Injury and Long-term Mortality Following Moderate to Severe Carbon Monoxide Poisoning|journal=JAMA|date=January 2006|volume=295|pages=398–402|doi= 10.1001/jama.295.4.398|pmid=16434630|issue= 4|url= http://jama.ama-assn.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=16434630|format= Free full text}} The carbon monoxide tolerance level for any person is altered by several factors, including activity level, [[Ventilation (physiology)|rate of ventilation]], a pre-existing [[Cerebrum|cerebral]] or [[cardiovascular disease]], [[cardiac output]], [[anemia]], [[sickle cell disease]] and other hematological disorders, [[barometric pressure]], and [[metabolic rate]].{{cite web|url=http://www.lungusa.org/site/pp.asp?c=dvLUK9O0E&b=35375|title=Carbon Monoxide|accessdate=2009-09-14|publisher=American Lung Association|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080528195959/http://www.lungusa.org/site/pp.asp?c=dvLUK9O0E&b=35375 |archivedate =2008-05-28|deadurl=yes}}{{cite journal|author=Lipman GS|title=Carbon monoxide toxicity at high altitude|journal=Wilderness & Environmental Medicine|year=2006|pages=144–45|volume=17|issue=2|pmid=16805152|doi=10.1580/1080-6032(2006)17[144:CMTAHA]2.0.CO;2}}{{cite book|author=first draft prepared by Mr J. Raub.|title=Environmental Health Criteria 213 (Carbon Monoxide)|publisher=International Programme on Chemical Safety, World Health Organization|location=Geneva|year=1999|pages=|isbn=9241572132}} {| class="wikitable" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; border: none;" |+Effects of carbon monoxide in relation to the concentration in parts per million in the air:{{cite journal|author=Goldstein M|title=Carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=Journal of Emergency Nursing|volume=34|issue=6|pages=538–42|date=December 2008|pmid=19022078|doi=10.1016/j.jen.2007.11.014}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Struttmann T, Scheerer A, Prince TS, Goldstein LA |title=Unintentional carbon monoxide poisoning from an unlikely source|journal=The Journal of the American Board of Family Practice|volume=11|issue=6|pages=481–84|date=Nov 1998|pmid=9876005|doi=10.3122/jabfm.11.6.481}} !Concentration !Symptoms |- |35 ppm (0.0035%) |Headache and dizziness within six to eight hours of constant exposure |- |100 ppm (0.01%) |Slight headache in two to three hours |- |200 ppm (0.02%) |Slight headache within two to three hours; loss of judgment |- |400 ppm (0.04%) |Frontal headache within one to two hours |- |800 ppm (0.08%) | Dizziness, nausea, and convulsions within 45 min; insensible within 2 hours |- |1,600 ppm (0.16%) |Headache, [[tachycardia|increased heart rate]], dizziness, and nausea within 20 min; death in less than 2 hours |- |3,200 ppm (0.32%) |Headache, dizziness and nausea in five to ten minutes. Death within 30 minutes. |- |6,400 ppm (0.64%) |Headache and dizziness in one to two minutes. Convulsions, respiratory arrest, and death in less than 20 minutes. |- |12,800 ppm (1.28%) |Unconsciousness after 2–3 breaths. Death in less than three minutes. |- |} === Acute poisoning === [[File:CO toxicity symptoms (en).jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|CO toxicity symptoms]] The main manifestations of carbon monoxide poisoning develop in the organ systems most dependent on oxygen use, the [[central nervous system]] and the [[heart]]. The initial symptoms of acute carbon monoxide poisoning include [[headache]], [[nausea]], [[malaise]], and [[fatigue (medical)|fatigue]].{{cite journal|vauthors=Hardy KR, Thom SR |title=Pathophysiology and treatment of carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=Journal of Toxicology. Clinical Toxicology|year=1994|pages=613–29|volume=32|issue=6|pmid=7966524|doi=10.3109/15563659409017973}} These symptoms are often mistaken for a virus such as [[influenza]] or other illnesses such as [[food poisoning]] or [[gastroenteritis]].{{cite book |title=Goldfrank's toxicologic emergencies |publisher=McGraw-Hill |location=New York |year=2002 |edition=7th |pages=1689–1704 |chapter=Carbon Monoxide |isbn=0071360018 |author1=Lewis Goldfrank |author2=Neal Flomenbaum |author3=Neal Lewin |author4=Mary Ann Howland |author5=Robert Hoffman |author6=Lewis Nelson}} Headache is the most common symptom of acute carbon monoxide poisoning; it is often described as dull, frontal, and continuous.{{cite journal|vauthors=Hampson NB, Hampson LA |title=Characteristics of headache associated with acute carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=Headache|volume=42|issue=3|pages=220–23|date=March 2002|pmid=11903546|doi=10.1046/j.1526-4610.2002.02055.x}} Increasing exposure produces cardiac abnormalities including [[tachycardia|fast heart rate]], [[hypotension|low blood pressure]], and [[cardiac arrhythmia]];{{cite journal |vauthors=Tritapepe L, Macchiarelli G, Rocco M, Scopinaro F, Schillaci O, Martuscelli E, Motta PM |title=Functional and ultrastructural evidence of myocardial stunning after acute carbon monoxide poisoning |journal=Critical Care Medicine |volume=26 |issue=4 |pages=797–801 |date=April 1998 |pmid=9559621 |doi=10.1097/00003246-199804000-00034}} [[central nervous system]] symptoms include [[delirium]], [[hallucination]]s, [[dizziness]], [[ataxia|unsteady gait]], [[confusion]], [[seizures]], [[central nervous system depression]], [[unconsciousness]], [[respiratory arrest]], and [[death]].{{cite journal|author=Weaver LK|title=Clinical practice. Carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=The New England Journal of Medicine|volume=360|issue=12|pages=1217–25|date=March 2009|pmid=19297574|doi=10.1056/NEJMcp0808891|url=http://content.nejm.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=short&pmid=19297574&promo=ONFLNS19}} Less common symptoms of acute carbon monoxide poisoning include [[myocardial ischemia]], [[atrial fibrillation]], [[pneumonia]], [[pulmonary edema]], [[hyperglycemia|high blood sugar]], [[lactic acidosis]], [[rhabdomyolysis|muscle necrosis]], [[acute kidney failure]], [[skin lesion]]s, and visual and auditory problems.{{cite journal|author=Choi IS|title=Carbon monoxide poisoning: systemic manifestations and complications|journal=Journal of Korean Medical Science|date=June 2001|pages=253–61|volume=16|issue=3|pmid=11410684|url=http://jkms.org/DOIx.php?id=10.3346/jkms.2001.16.3.253|doi-access=free |doi=10.3346/jkms.2001.16.3.253|pmc=3054741}}{{cite journal |author=Marius-Nunez AL |title=Myocardial infarction with normal coronary arteries after acute exposure to carbon monoxide |journal=Chest |volume=97 |issue=2 |pages=491–94 |date=February 1990 |pmid=2298080 |doi=10.1378/chest.97.2.491}}{{cite journal |vauthors=Gandini C, Castoldi AF, Candura SM, Locatelli C, Butera R, Priori S, Manzo L |title=Carbon monoxide cardiotoxicity |journal=Journal of Toxicology. Clinical Toxicology |volume=39 |issue=1 |pages=35–44 |year=2001 |pmid=11327225 |doi=10.1081/CLT-100102878}}{{cite journal |author=Sokal JA |title=The effect of exposure duration on the blood level of glucose, pyruvate and lactate in acute carbon monoxide intoxication in man |journal=Journal of Applied Toxicology: JAT |volume=5 |issue=6 |pages=395–97 |date=December 1985 |pmid=4078220 |doi=10.1002/jat.2550050611}} One of the major concerns following acute carbon monoxide poisoning is the severe delayed neurological manifestations that may occur. Problems may include difficulty with higher intellectual functions, [[memory loss|short-term memory loss]], [[dementia]], [[amnesia]], [[psychosis]], irritability, a strange [[gait]], speech disturbances, [[Parkinson's disease]]-like syndromes, [[cortical blindness]], and a [[Depression (mood)|depressed mood]].{{cite journal|author=Choi IS|title=Delayed neurologic sequelae in carbon monoxide intoxication|journal=Archives of Neurology|volume=40|issue=7|pages=433–35|date=July 1983|pmid=6860181|doi=10.1001/archneur.1983.04050070063016|url=http://archneur.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=582033|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120819232412/http://archneur.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=582033|archivedate=2012-08-19|df=}} Depression may occur in those who did not have pre-existing depression.{{cite journal|vauthors=Roohi F, Kula RW, Mehta N |title=Twenty-nine years after carbon monoxide intoxication|journal=Clinical Neurology and Neurosurgery|date=July 2001|pages=92–95|volume=103|issue=2|pmid=11516551|doi=10.1016/S0303-8467(01)00119-6}} These delayed neurological [[sequelae]] may occur in up to 50% of poisoned people after 2 to 40 days. It is difficult to predict who will develop delayed sequelae; however, advanced age, loss of consciousness while poisoned, and initial neurological abnormalities may increase the chance of developing delayed symptoms.{{cite journal|vauthors=Myers RA, Snyder SK, Emhoff TA |title=Subacute sequelae of carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=Annals of Emergency Medicine|volume=14|issue=12|pages=1163–67|date=December 1985|pmid=4061987|doi=10.1016/S0196-0644(85)81022-2}} One classic sign of carbon monoxide poisoning is more often seen in the dead rather than the living – people have been described as looking red-cheeked and healthy (see below). However, since this "cherry-red" appearance is common only in the deceased, and is unusual in living people, it is not considered a useful diagnostic sign in clinical medicine. In pathological (autopsy) examination the ruddy appearance of carbon monoxide poisoning is notable because unembalmed dead persons are normally bluish and pale, whereas dead carbon-monoxide poisoned persons may simply appear unusually lifelike in coloration.{{cite journal|author=Simini B|title=Cherry-red discolouration in carbon monoxide poisoning |journal=Lancet| volume=352|issue=9134| page=1154|date=October 1998|pmid=9798630|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(05)79807-X}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Brooks DE, Lin E, Ahktar J |title=What is cherry red, and who cares?|journal= [[The Journal of Emergency Medicine]] |date=February 2002|pages=213–14|volume=22|issue=2|pmid=11858933|doi=10.1016/S0736-4679(01)00469-3}} The colorant effect of carbon monoxide in such postmortem circumstances is thus analogous to its use as a red colorant in the commercial meat-packing industry. === Chronic poisoning === Chronic exposure to relatively low levels of carbon monoxide may cause persistent headaches, lightheadedness, depression, confusion, memory loss, nausea, hearing disorders and vomiting.{{cite journal|vauthors=Fawcett TA, Moon RE, Fracica PJ, Mebane GY, Theil DR, Piantadosi CA |title=Warehouse workers' headache. Carbon monoxide poisoning from propane-fueled forklifts|journal=Journal of Occupational Medicine|date=January 1992|pages=12–15|volume=34|issue=1|pmid=1552375}}{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/939229378|title=The Nordic Expert Group for criteria documentation of health risks from chemicals. 142, Occupational exposure to chemicals and hearing impairment|last=Johnson|first= Ann-Christin|date=2009|publisher=University of Gothenburg|others=Morata, Thais C.|isbn=978-9185971213|location=Göteborg|oclc=939229378}} It is unknown whether low-level chronic exposure may cause permanent neurological damage. Typically, upon removal from exposure to carbon monoxide, symptoms usually resolve themselves, unless there has been an episode of severe acute poisoning. However, one case noted permanent memory loss and learning problems after a 3-year exposure to relatively low levels of carbon monoxide from a faulty furnace.{{cite journal|author=Ryan CM|title=Memory disturbances following chronic, low-level carbon monoxide exposure|journal=Archives of Clinical Neuropsychology|year=1990|pages=59–67|volume=5|issue=1|pmid=14589544|doi=10.1016/0887-6177(90)90007-C}} Chronic exposure may worsen cardiovascular symptoms in some people. Chronic carbon monoxide exposure might increase the risk of developing atherosclerosis.{{cite journal|last=Davutoglu|first=V|title=Chronic carbon monoxide exposure is associated with the increases in carotid intima-media thickness and C-reactive protein level|journal=Tohoku J Exp Med|date=November 2009|volume=219|issue=3|pages=201–06|doi=10.1620/tjem.219.201|pmid=19851048}}{{cite book|last=Shephard|first=Roy|title=Carbon Monoxide The Silent Killer|year=1983|publisher=Charles C Thomas|location=Springfield Illinois|pages=93–96}} Long-term exposures to carbon monoxide present the greatest risk to persons with [[coronary heart disease]] and in females who are pregnant.{{cite journal|doi=10.1056/NEJM198911233212102|vauthors=Allred EN, Bleecker ER, Chaitman BR, Dahms TE, Gottlieb SO, Hackney JD, Pagano M, Selvester RH, Walden SM, Warren J |title=Short-term effects of carbon monoxide exposure on the exercise performance of subjects with coronary artery disease|journal=The New England Journal of Medicine|date=Nov 1989|pages=1426–32|volume=321|issue=21|pmid=2682242|url=}} In experimental animals, carbon monoxide appears to worsen noise-induced hearing loss at noise exposure conditions that would have limited effects on hearing otherwise.{{cite journal|last1=Fechter|first1=LD|title=Promotion of noise-induced hearing loss by chemical contaminants|journal=Journal of toxicology and environmental health. Part A|date=2004|volume=67|issue=8–10|pages=727–40|doi=10.1080/15287390490428206|pmid=15192865}} In humans, hearing loss has been reported following carbon monoxide poisoning. Unlike the findings in animal studies, noise exposure was not a necessary factor for the auditory problems to occur. == Causes == {| class="wikitable" style = "float: right; margin-left:15px; text-align:center" !Concentration !Source |- |0.1 ppm |Natural atmosphere level ([[MOPITT]]){{cite book | author =Committee on Medical and Biological Effects of Environmental Pollutants | title = Carbon Monoxide | publisher = National Academy of Sciences| location = Washington, DC| year =1977 | page = 29| doi = | isbn =0309026318 }} |- |0.5 to 5 ppm |Average level in homes{{cite web| title =An Introduction to Indoor Air Quality: Carbon Monoxide (CO)| author =Green W| publisher =United States Environmental Protection Agency| url =http://www.epa.gov/iaq/co.html| doi =| accessdate =2008-12-16| deadurl =no| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20081218112704/http://www.epa.gov/iaq/co.html| archivedate =2008-12-18| df =}} |- |5 to 15 ppm |Near properly adjusted gas stoves in homes |- |100 to 200 ppm |Exhaust from automobiles in the [[Mexico City]] central area{{cite book | last = Singer | first = Siegfried Fred | title = The Changing Global Environment | publisher = [[D. Reidel]] Publishing Company| location = Dordrecht| page = 90| doi = | isbn = }} |- |5,000 ppm |Exhaust from a home wood fire{{cite web | title =What Do Carbon Monoxide Levels Mean? | author =Gosink T | work =Alaska Science Forum | publisher =Geophysical Institute, University of Alaska Fairbanks | date =1983-01-28 | url =http://www.gi.alaska.edu/ScienceForum/ASF5/588.html | accessdate =2008-12-16 | deadurl =no | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20081225113654/http://www.gi.alaska.edu/ScienceForum/ASF5/588.html | archivedate =2008-12-25 | df = }} |- |7,000 ppm |Undiluted warm car exhaust without a [[catalytic converter]] |- |30,000 ppm |[[Afterdamp]] following an explosion in a coal mine{{citation | last = Roberts | first = H C W | title = Report on the causes of, and circumstances attending, the explosion which occurred at Easington Colliery, County Durham, on the 29th May, 1951. | date = September 1952 | publisher = Her Majesty's Stationery Office | publication-place = London | series = Cmd 8646 | format = PDF | url = http://hdl.handle.net/1842/5365 | page = 39 }} |} Carbon monoxide is a product of combustion of organic matter under conditions of restricted oxygen supply, which prevents complete [[oxidation]] to [[carbon dioxide]] (CO2). Sources of carbon monoxide include cigarette smoke, house fires, faulty [[furnace]]s, heaters, [[wood-burning stove]]s,{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/man-died-from-carbon-monoxide-poisoning-after-using-heat-beads-in-greystanes-home-20150718-gif8d8.html|title=Man died from carbon monoxide poisoning after using 'heat beads' in Greystanes home|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150719131747/http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/man-died-from-carbon-monoxide-poisoning-after-using-heat-beads-in-greystanes-home-20150718-gif8d8.html|archivedate=2015-07-19|df=}} [[internal combustion]] [[vehicle exhaust]], [[electrical generator]]s, [[propane]]-fueled equipment such as portable stoves, and gasoline-powered tools such as [[leaf blower]]s, lawn mowers, high-pressure washers, concrete cutting saws, power trowels, and welders.{{cite journal|vauthors=Marc B, Bouchez-Buvry A, Wepierre JL, Boniol L, Vaquero P, Garnier M |title=Carbon-monoxide poisoning in young drug addicts due to indoor use of a gasoline-powered generator|journal=Journal of Clinical Forensic Medicine|volume=8|issue=2|pages=54–56|date=June 2001|pmid=16083675|doi=10.1054/jcfm.2001.0474}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Johnson C, Moran J, Paine S, Anderson H, Breysse P |title=Abatement of toxic levels of carbon monoxide in Seattle ice-skating rinks|journal=American Journal of Public Health|volume=65|issue=10|pages=1087–90|date=October 1975|pmid=1163706|doi=10.2105/AJPH.65.10.1087|pmc=1776025}}{{cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/topics/co/|title=NIOSH Carbon Monoxide Hazards from Small Gasoline Powered Engines|accessdate=2007-10-15|publisher=United States National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071029032750/http://www.cdc.gov/niosh/topics/co/|archivedate=2007-10-29|df=}}{{cite journal |vauthors=Fife CE, Smith LA, Maus EA, McCarthy JJ, Koehler MZ, Hawkins T, Hampson NB |title=Dying to play video games: carbon monoxide poisoning from electrical generators used after hurricane Ike |journal=Pediatrics |volume=123 |issue=6 |pages=e1035–38 |date=June 2009 |pmid=19482736 |doi=10.1542/peds.2008-3273}}{{cite report|author=Emmerich, SJ|date=July 2011|title=Measured CO Concentrations at NIST IAQ Test House from Operation of Portable Electric Generators in Attached Garage – Interim Report|url=https://www.nist.gov/manuscript-publication-search.cfm?pub_id=907771|publisher=United States National Institute of Standards and Technology|accessdate=2012-04-18|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130224044200/http://nist.gov/manuscript-publication-search.cfm?pub_id=907771|archivedate=2013-02-24|df=}} Exposure typically occurs when equipment is used in buildings or semi-enclosed spaces. Riding in the back of [[pickup trucks]] has led to poisoning in children.{{cite journal|vauthors=Hampson NB, Norkool DM |title=Carbon monoxide poisoning in children riding in the back of pickup trucks|journal=JAMA|volume=267|issue=4|pages=538–40|date=January 1992|pmid=1370334|doi=10.1001/jama.267.4.538|url=}} Idling automobiles with the exhaust pipe blocked by snow has led to the poisoning of car occupants.{{cite journal|author=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)|title=Carbon monoxide poisonings associated with snow-obstructed vehicle exhaust systems—Philadelphia and New York City, January 1996|journal=MMWR. Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report|volume=45|issue=1|pages=1–3|date=January 1996|pmid=8531914|url=https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00039929.htm|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170624015949/https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00039929.htm|archivedate=2017-06-24|df=}} Any perforation between the exhaust manifold and shroud can result in exhaust gases reaching the cabin. Generators and propulsion engines on boats, especially houseboats, has resulted in fatal carbon monoxide exposures.{{cite journal |author=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)|title=Houseboat-associated carbon monoxide poisonings on Lake Powell—Arizona and Utah, 2000|journal=MMWR. Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report|volume=49|issue=49|pages=1105–1108|date=December 2000|pmid=11917924|url=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/topics/coboating/|title=NIOSH Carbon Monoxide Dangers in Boating|accessdate=2007-10-15|publisher=United States National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071013113132/http://cdc.gov/niosh/topics/coboating/|archivedate=2007-10-13|df=}} Poisoning may also occur following the use of a self-contained underwater breathing apparatus (SCUBA) due to faulty [[diving air compressor]]s.{{cite journal|vauthors=Austin CC, Ecobichon DJ, Dussault G, Tirado C |title=Carbon monoxide and water vapor contamination of compressed breathing air for firefighters and divers|journal=Journal of Toxicology and Environmental Health|volume=52|issue=5|pages=403–23|date=December 1997|pmid=9388533|doi=10.1080/00984109708984073}} In caves carbon monoxide can build up in enclosed chambers due to the presence of decomposing organic matter.{{cite book |last=Dart| first= RC |chapter= |title=Medical toxicology |publisher=Williams & Wilkins| location=Philadelphia |year=2004|page=1169| isbn=0781728452}} In coal mines incomplete combustion may occur during explosions resulting in the production of [[afterdamp]]. The gas is up to 3% CO and may be fatal after just a single breath. Following an explosion in a colliery, adjacent interconnected mines may become dangerous due to the afterdamp leaking from mine to mine. Such an incident followed the [[Trimdon Grange]] explosion which killed men in the [[Kelloe]] mine.{{citation | url = http://www.healeyhero.co.uk/rescue/pits/Trimdon_Grange/Trimdon3.htm#top | title = Trimdon Grange, Durham. 16th February 1882 | accessdate = 22 May 2012 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170330072644/http://www.healeyhero.co.uk/rescue/pits/Trimdon_Grange/Trimdon3.htm#top | archivedate = 30 March 2017 | df = }} Another source of poisoning is exposure to the organic solvent [[dichloromethane]], found in some [[paint stripper]]s,{{cite journal|last=van Veen|first=MP|author2=Fortezza F |author3=Spaans E |author4=Mensinga TT |title=Non-professional paint stripping, model prediction and experimental validation of indoor dichloromethane levels|journal=Indoor Air|year=2002|volume=12|issue=2|pages=92–97|doi=10.1034/j.1600-0668.2002.01109.x|pmid=12216472}} as the metabolism of dichloromethane produces carbon monoxide.{{cite journal|vauthors=Kubic VL, Anders MW |title=Metabolism of dihalomethanes to carbon monoxide. II. In vitro studies|journal=Drug Metabolism and Disposition|date=March 1975|pages=104–12|volume=3|issue=2|pmid=236156}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Dueñas A, Felipe S, Ruiz-Mambrilla M, Martín-Escudero JC, García-Calvo C |title=CO poisoning caused by inhalation of CH3Cl contained in personal defense spray|journal=The American Journal of Emergency Medicine|volume=18|issue=1|pages=120–21|date=January 2000|pmid=10674554|doi=10.1016/S0735-6757(00)90070-6}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Varon J, Marik PE, Fromm RE, Gueler A |title=Carbon monoxide poisoning: A review for clinicians|journal= [[The Journal of Emergency Medicine]] |year=1999|pages=87–93|volume=17|issue=1|pmid=9950394|doi=10.1016/S0736-4679(98)00128-0}} == Pathophysiology == The precise mechanisms by which the effects of carbon monoxide are induced upon bodily systems, are complex and not yet fully understood. Known mechanisms include carbon monoxide binding to [[hemoglobin]], [[myoglobin]] and [[mitochondrial]] [[cytochrome oxidase]] and restricting oxygen supply, and carbon monoxide causing [[brain]] [[lipid peroxidation]].{{cite journal|author=Bateman DN|title=Carbon Monoxide|journal=Medicine|volume=31|issue=10|page=233|date=October 2003|doi=10.1383/medc.31.10.41.27810}} === Hemoglobin === [[File:Hemoglobin saturation curve.svg|thumb|Carbon monoxide shifts the oxygen-dissociation curve to the left.]] Carbon monoxide has a higher diffusion coefficient compared to oxygen, and the only enzyme in the human body that produces carbon monoxide is [[heme oxygenase]], which is located in all cells and breaks down [[heme]]. Under normal conditions, carbon monoxide levels in the [[Blood plasma|plasma]] are approximately 0 [[Millimeter of mercury|mmHg]] because it has a higher diffusion coefficient and the body easily gets rid of any CO made.{{cite book|title=USMLE Step 1 Lecture Notes: Physiology|year=2011|author=Dunn, Robert B.|author2=Kudrath, W. |author3=Passo, SS |author4=Wilson, LB|pages=167–68|chapter=7-3}} When CO is not ventilated it binds to hemoglobin, which is the principal oxygen-carrying compound in blood; this produces a compound known as [[carboxyhemoglobin]]. The traditional belief is that carbon monoxide toxicity arises from the formation of carboxyhemoglobin, which decreases the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood and inhibits the transport, delivery, and utilization of oxygen by the body. The affinity between hemoglobin and carbon monoxide is approximately 230 times stronger than the affinity between hemoglobin and oxygen so hemoglobin binds to carbon monoxide in preference to oxygen.{{cite journal|vauthors=Townsend CL, Maynard RL |title=Effects on health of prolonged exposure to low concentrations of carbon monoxide|journal=Occupational and Environmental Medicine|volume=59|issue=10|pages=708–11|date=October 2002|pmid=12356933|pmc=1740215|doi=10.1136/oem.59.10.708|url=}}{{cite journal|author=Haldane J|title=The action of carbonic oxide on man|journal=The Journal of Physiology|year=1895|pages=430–62|volume=18|url=http://jp.physoc.org/content/18/5-6/430.full.pdf|pmid=16992272|issue=5–6|pmc=1514663|doi=10.1113/jphysiol.1895.sp000578|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708152937/http://jp.physoc.org/content/18/5-6/430.full.pdf|archivedate=2011-07-08|df=}} Hemoglobin is a [[Tetrameric protein|tetramer]] with four oxygen binding sites. The binding of carbon monoxide at one of these sites increases the oxygen affinity of the remaining three sites, which causes the hemoglobin molecule to retain oxygen that would otherwise be delivered to the tissue.{{cite journal|vauthors=Gorman D, Drewry A, Huang YL, Sames C |title=The clinical toxicology of carbon monoxide|journal=Toxicology|date=May 2003|pages=25–38|volume=187|issue=1|pmid=12679050|doi=10.1016/S0300-483X(03)00005-2}} This situation is described as carbon monoxide shifting the [[oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve|oxygen dissociation curve]] to the left. Because of the increased affinity between hemoglobin and oxygen during carbon monoxide poisoning, little oxygen will actually be released in the tissues. This causes hypoxic tissue injury. Hemoglobin acquires a bright red color when converted into carboxyhemoglobin, so poisoned cadavers and even commercial meats treated with carbon monoxide acquire an unnatural reddish hue. === Myoglobin === Carbon monoxide also binds to the [[hemeprotein]] [[myoglobin]]. It has a high affinity for myoglobin, about 60 times greater than that of oxygen. Carbon monoxide bound to myoglobin may impair its ability to utilize oxygen. This causes reduced [[cardiac output]] and [[hypotension]], which may result in [[brain ischemia]]. A delayed return of symptoms have been reported. This results following a recurrence of increased carboxyhemoglobin levels; this effect may be due to a late release of carbon monoxide from myoglobin, which subsequently binds to hemoglobin. === Cytochrome oxidase === Another mechanism involves effects on the mitochondrial respiratory enzyme chain that is responsible for effective tissue utilization of oxygen. Carbon monoxide binds to [[cytochrome oxidase]] with less affinity than oxygen, so it is possible that it requires significant intracellular hypoxia before binding.{{cite journal |vauthors=Gorman DF, Runciman WB |title=Carbon monoxide poisoning |journal=Anaesthesia and Intensive Care |volume=19 |issue=4 |pages=506–11 |date=November 1991 |pmid=1750629 |doi= |url=}} This binding interferes with aerobic metabolism and efficient [[adenosine triphosphate]] synthesis. Cells respond by switching to [[anaerobic metabolism]], causing [[Hypoxia (medical)|anoxia]], [[lactic acidosis]], and eventual cell death.{{cite journal|vauthors=Alonso JR, Cardellach F, Lopez S, Casademont J, Miro O |title=Carbon monoxide specifically inhibits cytochrome c oxidase of human mitochondrial respiratory chain|journal=Pharmacology & Toxicology|date=September 2003|pages=142–46|volume=93|issue=3|pmid=12969439|doi=10.1034/j.1600-0773.2003.930306.x}} The rate of [[Dissociation (chemistry)|dissociation]] between carbon monoxide and cytochrome oxidase is slow, causing a relatively prolonged impairment of [[oxidative metabolism]]. === Central nervous system effects === The mechanism that is thought to have a significant influence on delayed effects involves formed blood cells and chemical mediators, which cause brain [[lipid peroxidation]] (degradation of unsaturated fatty acids). Carbon monoxide causes [[endothelial]] cell and platelet release of [[nitric oxide]], and the formation of [[oxygen free radicals]] including [[peroxynitrite]]. In the brain this causes further mitochondrial dysfunction, [[capillary]] leakage, [[leukocyte]] sequestration, and [[apoptosis]].{{cite journal|author=Blumenthal I|title=Carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine|date=June 2001|pages=270–72|volume=94|issue=6|pmid=11387414|url=http://www.jrsm.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=11387414|format=Free full text|pmc=1281520|doi=10.1177/014107680109400604}} The result of these effects is [[lipid peroxidation]], which causes delayed reversible [[Demyelinating disease|demyelinization]] of [[white matter]] in the central nervous system known as [[Grinker myelinopathy]], which can lead to [[edema]] and [[necrosis]] within the brain. This brain damage occurs mainly during the recovery period. This may result in cognitive defects, especially affecting memory and learning, and movement disorders. These disorders are typically related to damage to the cerebral [[white matter]] and [[basal ganglia]].{{cite journal|vauthors=Fan HC, Wang AC, Lo CP, Chang KP, Chen SJ |title=Damage of cerebellar white matter due to carbon monoxide poisoning: a case report|journal=[[The American Journal of Emergency Medicine]]|volume=27|issue=6|pages=757.e5–e7|date=July 2009|pmid=19751650|doi=10.1016/j.ajem.2008.10.021}} Hallmark pathological changes following poisoning are bilateral necrosis of the white matter, [[globus pallidus]], [[cerebellum]], [[hippocampus]] and the [[cerebral cortex]].{{cite journal|vauthors=Prockop LD, Chichkova RI |title=Carbon monoxide intoxication: an updated review|journal=Journal of the Neurological Sciences|date=Nov 2007|pages=122–30|volume=262|issue=1–2|pmid=17720201|doi=10.1016/j.jns.2007.06.037}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Fukuhara M, Abe I, Matsumura K, Kaseda S, Yamashita Y, Shida K, Kawashima H, Fujishima M |title=Circadian variations of blood pressure in patients with sequelae of carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=American Journal of Hypertension |volume=9|issue=4 Part 1|pages=300–05|date=April 1996|pmid=8722431|doi=10.1016/0895-7061(95)00342-8}} === Pregnancy === Carbon monoxide poisoning in pregnant women may cause severe adverse [[fetus|fetal]] effects.
