revision.text:
'''Bruce Robert Isabell''' (June 2, 1952 – July 8, 2009) was an [[United States|American]] [[Event planning|event planner]] who was behind lavish and innovative events including weddings and funerals of the richest and most famous. He helped make Christmas at the [[White House]] during the [[Presidency of Bill Clinton]] and helped create innovative events that made [[Studio 54]] in [[Manhattan]] into the place to be in the late 1970s and early 1980s.
Isabell was born in [[Duluth, Minnesota]], where he worked in a flower shop as a youth. After graduating from high school he moved to [[Minneapolis]].<ref name=NYTObit>Weber, Bruce. [https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/11/nyregion/11isabell.html "Robert Isabell, Who Turned Events Into Wondrous Occasions, Dies at 57"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', July 10, 2009. Accessed July 14, 2009.</ref>
He moved to [[New York City]] in the 1970s and was hired by [[Ian Schrager]] at [[Studio 54]], after Schrager had seen the creative designs Isabell had developed while he was working for event planner Renny Reynolds who had done work at the club and was the leading planner in his day. Schrager described how Isabell "never tried to do too much, it was never design on steroids, yet there was always the razzle-dazzle".<ref name=NYTObit/>
He started on his own operating a floral shop within [[Bergdorf Goodman]] in [[Midtown Manhattan]]. He established "a full-service event-production house" in the city's [[West Village]] where he would oversee the creation of events around the world, in which the entire setting including flowers, lighting, sound and table decorations would be part of his craft. [[Anna Wintour]] of ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]'' magazine described him as "the king of the event world" who was "a magician"<ref name="NYTObit" /> and the first person that top hostesses would approach to create spectacular events. Isabell created roughly 30 events for writer and editor [[Tina Brown]]. She regarded him as "sort of a genius" who had the ability to "take any space and make magic in it".<ref name=NYTObit/> For over a decade, he designed the annual [[Met Ball]] for ''Vogue''.<ref name=TCBG>{{cite web|url=http://nymag.com/nymetro/shopping/fashion/features/11894/|title=The Charity Ball Game|accessdate=2011-05-04|date=2005-05-21|work=[[New York (magazine)|New York]]}}</ref>
In the late 1970s, he had four tons of [[glitter]] dumped on the floor of [[Studio 54]] for a New Year's Eve event, with club co-owner Ian Schrager describing how guests felt "like you were standing on stardust".<ref name=NYTObit/> Bracketed between the 1986 wedding of [[Edwin Schlossberg]] to [[Caroline Kennedy]] and the 1996 nuptials of [[John F. Kennedy, Jr.]] and [[Carolyn Bessette]], he worked on the 1994 funeral of [[Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis]].<ref name=NYTObit/> For the July 1995 wedding of billionaire [[Robert Warren Miller]]'s daughter [[Marie-Chantal, Crown Princess of Greece|Marie-Chantal]] to [[Pavlos, Crown Prince of Greece]] at [[Saint Sophia (London)|Saint Sophia]] in [[Bayswater]], [[London]], Isabell created a virtual Greek temple in a tent, including pillars topped with roses, with a budget variously estimated at $5–8 million.<ref>Morris, Bob. [https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/18/garden/at-home-and-work-with-robert-isabell-coming-to-the-aid-of-the-party.html "AT HOME AND AT WORK WITH: Robert Isabell; Coming to the Aid Of the Party"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', April 18, 1996. Accessed July 14, 2009.</ref> For the wedding of [[Alexandra von Fürstenberg]], Marie-Chantal's sister, to Prince Alexandre Egon von Fürstenberg, son of [[Diane von Fürstenberg]], Isabell transformed a tent in [[Battery Park]] into a Chinese teahouse complete with a throne room that included hanging lanterns and bamboo trees.<ref>[[Suzy Menkes|Menkes, Suzy]]. [https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/24/style/runways-high-society-transforms-itself-into-shy-society.html "RUNWAYS; High Society Transforms Itself Into Shy Society"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', December 24, 1995. Accessed July 14, 2009.</ref> For Christmas 1998 at the Clinton White House, Isabell created a massive fir wreath with 1,500 lights individually colored a shade he called "Presidential blue".<ref>Bumiller, Elizabeth. [https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/22/nyregion/a-star-floral-designer-s-flights-of-fancy.html "A Star Floral Designer's Flights of Fancy"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', December 22, 1998. Accessed July 14, 2009.</ref>
His last project was an [[Independence Day (United States)|Independence Day]] event he co-prepared for [[Lally Weymouth]] in [[Southampton (town), New York|Southampton, New York]].<ref name=WWDObit>Feitelberg, Rosemary. [http://www.wwd.com/lifestyle-news/robert-isabell-a-list-party-planner-dies-2209256?gnewsid=bd9eca87a8f58bd9363f4db087fd936b "Robert Isabell, A-List Party Planner, Dies"], ''[[Women's Wear Daily]]'', July 10, 2009. Accessed July 10, 2009.</ref> [[Ian Schrager]] stated that Isabell had headed home from [[The Hamptons]] on the night of July 4 and had not been heard from before his death.<ref name=NYTObit/>
A resident of [[Manhattan]]'s [[Greenwich Village]], Isabell was found dead on July 8, 2009, aged 57, in his townhouse at 16 Minetta Lane, where he had suffered a fatal [[myocardial infarction]] (heart attack). He is survived by his mother, two brothers and a sister.<ref name=NYTObit/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Isabell, Robert}} [[Category:1952 births]] [[Category:2009 deaths]] [[Category:American entertainment industry businesspeople]] [[Category:American socialites]] [[Category:People from Duluth, Minnesota]] [[Category:People from Greenwich Village]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Minneapolis]] [[Category:Event planners]]

'''Shawn Rabideau''' (born February 9, 1975) is an American born lifestyle expert and event planner whose work has been featured in numerous television series including "Best Night In" on TVLand, Seasons 8 and 9 of "[[Whose Wedding Is It Anyway?]]" on the [[Style Network]].<ref name="tvwatch-people">[http://tvwatch.people.com/2010/06/23/bethenny-getting-married-wedding-planner/ People.com]</ref>
Rabideau was also cast to star in the pilot episode of "In Full Bloom" on the [[Halogen TV|Halogen Network]]. In 2010 he was the Wedding Planner for the hit series "[[Bethenny Ever After...|Bethenny Getting Married?]]" on [[Bravo (US TV channel)|Bravo]], and in 2011 he was cast in the second season of "Bethenny Getting Married?", retitled "[[Bethenny Ever After...]]" on [[Bravo (US TV channel)|Bravo]].<ref name="salon">[http://www.salon.com/entertainment/tv/bethenny_getting_married/?story=/ent/tv/heather_havrilesky/2010/07/03/bethenny_gets_married Salon.com]</ref>
Rabideau is widely recognized for his eye for design and has worked with numerous celebrities including [[Barbara Walters]], [[Jennifer Lopez]], [[Star Jones]], and [[Bethenny Frankel]]. He has served as the lifestyle expert for [[WHAM-TV|ABC 13]] and has been a featured wedding expert on ABC's "Good Morning America,". Recently Rabideau has been a featured lifestyle and entertaining expert on VH1's "Big Morning Buzz", TV Land's "Best Night In", Better TV, CBS WLNY's "Live from the Couch" and Fox News Live where he is known for his entertaining "Rabidos" and "Rabidon'ts". He has developed a design sense that has been portrayed in magazines and newspapers including ''[[The New York Times]]'', ''[[The New York Post]]'', ''[[Woman's World|Women's World]]'' and ''[[OK! Magazine]]''.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{Official website|1=http://www.shawnrabideau.com/}} * {{imdb name|3227538}} * [http://www.bravotv.com/bethenny-getting-married/blogs/shawn-rabideau/stuck-on-the-damn-cake Shawn Rabideau blog] at [[Bravo (US TV channel)|Bravo TV]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Rabideau, Shawn}} [[Category:American television personalities]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1975 births]] [[Category:Event planners]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox organization | key_people = [[Sue Gardner]], Executive Director
[[Julia Angwin]] and [[Jeff Larson (journalist)|Jeff Larson]], Founders | footnotes = | name = The Markup | founded_date = {{start date and age|2019}} | founder = | location = [[Manhattan]] | origins = | area_served = [[United States]] | focus = [[Investigative journalism]], [[technology]] | method = | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_members = | owner = | Non-profit_slogan = | homepage = {{url|themarkup.org}} | dissolved = }}'''''The Markup''''' is an American [[nonprofit organization]] based in [[New York City]] that will focus on [[Data-driven journalism|data driven journalism]] covering the ethics and impact of technology on society. Markup was co-founded by two former [[ProPublica]] journalists [[Julia Angwin]] and [[Jeff Larson (journalist)|Jeff Larson]]. The idea was conceived in April 2018, and expects to launch in early 2019.{{Cite news|url=http://www.niemanlab.org/2018/04/former-propublica-journalists-are-launching-a-newsroom-to-cover-the-impact-of-technology-on-society/|title=Former ProPublica journalists are launching a newsroom to cover the impact of technology on society|last=Owen|first=Laura H.|date=2018-04-12|work=Nieman Lab|access-date=2018-09-23}} Like ProPublica, all of their content will be licensed under a [[Creative Commons license]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/23/business/media/the-markup-craig-newmark.html|title=News Site to Investigate Big Tech, Helped by Craigslist Founder|last=Bowles|first=Nellie|date=2018-09-23|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en}} == Data journalism == According to Julia Angwin, The Markup plans to collect and create public data sets through [[Freedom of Information Act (United States)|public records]] requests, automated data collection, crowdsourcing of information and creation of tools, for example at ProPublica they built a browser extension to analyze [[Facebook]] ads.{{Cite news|url=https://www.recode.net/2018/9/27/17908798/julia-angwin-markup-jeff-larson-craig-newmark-data-investigative-journalism-peter-kafka-podcast|title=It may be ‘data journalism,’ but Julia Angwin’s new site the Markup is nothing like FiveThirtyEight|work=Recode|access-date=2018-10-01}} == Funding == The Markup received $20 million gift from [[Craigslist]] founder [[Craig Newmark]]. They also raised $2 million from the [[John S. and James L. Knight Foundation|Knight Foundation]] and an additional $1 million from [[Ford Foundation]], [[MacArthur Foundation]] and the Ethics and Governance of Artificial Intelligence Initiative. ==Sources== [[Category:Stub-Class AfC articles]] [[Category:News]] [[Category:Technology websites]] [[Category:Media in New York City]] [[Category:American news websites]] {{nonprofit-org-stub}} {{journalism-stub}}

revision.comment: I made Kara Tointon into a hyperlink!!!
revision.text:
{{italic title}} {{Distinguish|The Sound of Music Live!}} '''''The Sound of Music Live''''' is a [[television special]] that was originally broadcast by [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] on 20 December 2015. The special was an adaptation of [[Rodgers and Hammerstein]]'s Broadway musical ''[[The Sound of Music]]'', starring [[Kara Tointon]] as [[Maria von Trapp]], performed and televised [[live television|live]] from [[3 Mills Studios]] in London.
On 9 November 2018, the production was broadcast in the United States as part of [[PBS]]'s performing arts anthology series ''[[Great Performances]]''.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.unionleader.com/great-performances-imports-uk-s-sound-of-music/article_f1a6feb2-4b7f-57f9-9a41-e05aa84a76de.html|title='Great Performances' imports UK's 'Sound of Music'|work=UnionLeader.com|access-date=2018-11-10|language=en}}</ref>
== Production == In October 2015, ITV announced that it would transmit a live adaptation of the musical ''[[The Sound of Music]]'' as part of its holiday programming lineup, in what would be the first time that such a programme had been attempted in the United Kingdom.<ref name="deadline-itvsom">{{cite web|title=ITV To Mount ‘The Sound Of Music Live!’ UK Christmas Special|url=http://deadline.com/2015/10/itv-sound-of-music-live-christmas-special-kara-tointon-1201590814/|website=Deadline.com|accessdate=2 February 2016}}</ref> ''The Sound of Music Live'' was part of ITV's continuing efforts to broadcast more live "[[Event television|event]]" programs, which are designed to attract critical masses of viewers by encouraging them to watch via the original broadcast, rather than via [[video on demand|catch-up]] services and [[digital video recorder]]s. The desire for increased ITV viewership came especially in the wake of declining ratings for its reality music competition ''[[The X Factor (UK)|The X Factor]]'', whose [[The X Factor (UK series 12)|series 12]] finale had the second-smallest viewership in the programme's history. ITV had similarly broadcast live episodes of its series ''[[Coronation Street]]'' in [[Coronation Street Live (2000 episode)|2000]] and [[Coronation Street Live (2010 episode)|2010]] in honour of its 40th and 50th anniversary respectively, and in 2015 for ITV's 60th anniversary.<ref name="deadline-itvsom"/>
This was not the first time that ''The Sound of Music'' had been adapted in such a manner. In 2013, U.S. network [[NBC]] broadcast its own [[The Sound of Music Live!|live television adaptation of ''The Sound of Music'']] starring [[country music|country]] singer [[Carrie Underwood]]; similarly to ITV's version, it was an adaptation of the original musical, and not based on the [[The Sound of Music|film version]]. Although it received mixed reviews, it was seen by over 18 million viewers. As follow-ups, NBC produced similar adaptations of ''[[Peter Pan Live!|Peter Pan]]'' and ''[[The Wiz Live!|The Wiz]]'' in 2014 and 2015 respectively.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newsday.com/entertainment/tv/the-wiz-live-nbc-s-latest-live-musical-broadcast-from-long-island-1.11164689|title=‘The Wiz Live!’: NBC’s latest live musical broadcast from Long Island|last1=Crook|first1=John|date=26 November 2015|website=newsday.com |publisher=Newsday|access-date=26 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://tvline.com/2013/12/06/sound-of-music-live-ratings-nbc/ |title=Ratings: NBC's Sound of Music Live! Does Something Very Good; Glee and Grey's Eye Lows |last=Mitovich|first=Matt Webb |date=December 6, 2013 |work=TVLine |accessdate=December 7, 2013}}</ref> Creative director [[Coky Giedroyc]] stated that ITV's iteration would be a "whole different animal" in comparison to NBC's, explaining that she wanted to "keep it true to the original", and maintain a focus on the political aspects of the story.<ref name="rt-differences">{{cite web|title=How will The Sound of Music Live work?|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/news/2015-12-20/how-will-the-sound-of-music-live-work|website=Radio Times|accessdate=2 February 2016}}</ref><ref name="guardian-future">{{cite web|last1=Martinson|first1=Jane|title=As ITV prepares for the Sound of Music Live, are we watching TV's future?| url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2015/dec/15/as-itv-prepares-for-the-sound-of-music-live-are-we-watching-tvs-future|website=The Guardian|accessdate=21 December 2015}}</ref> The production was conducted on soundstages at [[3 Mills Studios]] in London, with the sets alone having a budget of nearly £750,000.<ref name="rt-differences"/>
==Cast== [[Kara Tointon]] played Maria, and [[Julian Ovenden]] played Captain Georg von Trapp. The supporting cast included veterans of British television and theatre, including [[Alexander Armstrong]] as Max Detweiler, [[Katherine Kelly (actress)|Katherine Kelly]] as Baroness Elsa Schraeder, [[Maria Friedman]] as Mother Abess, [[Evelyn Hoskins]] as Liesl von Trapp, Jon Tarcy as Rolf Gruber, [[Mel Giedroyc]] as the housekeeper, Frau Schmidt, and [[Paul Copley]] as the butler, Franz.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Sound of Music Live!|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/episode/dwnsbw/the-sound-of-music-live|website=Radio Times|accessdate=21 December 2015}}</ref>
==Reception== ''The Sound of Music Live'' received mixed reviews. Mark Shenton of ''[[The Stage]]'' said it was a failed experiment, with "uninspired and sometimes insipid" choreography and direction, although he praised the cast's performances.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Shenton|first1=Mark|title=The Sound of Music Live review – ‘bold experiment doesn’t pay off’|url=https://www.thestage.co.uk/reviews/2015/the-sound-of-music-live-review-bold-experiment-doesnt-pay-off/|website=The Stage|accessdate=21 December 2015}}</ref> Claire Allfree of ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' said it lacked both the intimacy of live theatre and the scope of the big screen, but nevertheless judged it "more a success than it was a failure," saying that former ''[[EastEnders]]'' star Tointon "brought a refreshing earthiness and grit to Maria that made the passionate, unconventional novice feel thoroughly modern and accessible."<ref>{{cite web|title=The Sound of Music Live, review: 'much to enjoy'|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/tv-and-radio-reviews/12056862/the-sound-of-music-review-kara-tointon-live-itv.html|website=The Telegraph|accessdate=21 December 2015}}</ref> ''[[Daily Mirror|The Mirror]]'' said that Tointon was "showered with praise" for her performance.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kara Tointon shocks fans with incredible vocals as she plays Maria in The Sound Of Music live|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/tv/tv-news/kara-tointon-shocks-fans-incredible-7048037|website=The Mirror|accessdate=21 December 2015}}</ref>
The programme was watched by over 3.82 million viewers according to overnight ratings figures, being beaten by the [[The Apprentice (UK series eleven)|series eleven]] finale of ''[[The Apprentice (UK TV series)|The Apprentice]]'' (5.31 million) and its lead-in, the [[2015 BBC Sports Personality of the Year Award|BBC Sports Personality of the Year]] presentation (5.78 million).<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.digitalspy.com/tv/the-apprentice/news/a777848/uk-tv-ratings-the-apprentice-final-loses-800000-from-last-year-sports-personality-is-top-with-57m/ |title=UK TV ratings: The Apprentice final is lowest in 10 years, Sports Personality is top with 5.7m |author=Tom Eames |work=Digital Spy }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=ITV's The Sound of Music Live draws 4m viewers|url=https://www.thestage.co.uk/news/2015/itvs-the-sound-of-music-live-draws-4m-viewers/|website=The Stage|accessdate=21 December 2015}}</ref>
==See also== * [[2015 in British television]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
{{The Story of the Trapp Family Singers}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Sound of Music Live (2015), The}} [[Category:2015 in British television]] [[Category:2015 television specials]] [[Category:British television specials]] [[Category:English-language television programs]] [[Category:ITV television programmes]] [[Category:Live television programs]] [[Category:Musical television films]] [[Category:Musical television specials]] [[Category:Television programs based on plays]] [[Category:Television remakes of films]] [[Category:The Sound of Music]] [[Category:Trapp family]] [[Category:Works based on actual events]]

[[File:Lockerbie disaster memorial.jpg|right|thumb|300px|A memorial is often established to remember lives lost in a tragedy such as the [[Lockerbie air disaster]]]] A '''tragedy''' is an event of great loss, usually of human life. Such an event is said to be ''tragic''. Traditionally the event would require "some element of moral failure, some flaw in character, or some extraordinary combination of elements"<ref>http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19920405&slug=1484688</ref> to be tragic.
Not all death is considered a tragedy. Rather it is a precise set of symptoms surrounding the loss that define it as such.<ref>{{cite book |title=Crisis Intervention Training for Disaster Workers: An Introduction |last=Doherty |first=George W. |authorlink= |publisher= |location= |isbn= |page=12 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref> There are a variety of factors that define a death as ''tragic''.
An event in which a massive number of deaths occur may be seen as a tragedy. This can be re-enforced by media attention or other public outcry.<ref name=Lattanzi1>{{cite book |title=Coping with public tragedy |last=Lattanzi-Licht |first=Marcia E. |authorlink= |author2=Kenneth J. Doka |publisher= |location= |isbn= |page=1 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref>
A tragedy does not necessarily involve [[massacre|massive death]]. The death of a single person, e.g., a public figure or a child, may be seen as a tragedy.<ref name=Lattanzi1/> The person need not necessarily have been [[celebrity|famous]] before death.
==Factors that make death a tragedy== Generally, the label of "tragedy" is given to an event based on public perception.<ref>{{cite book |title=Coping with public tragedy |last=Lattanzi-Licht |first=Marcia E. |authorlink= |author2=Kenneth J. Doka |publisher= |location= |isbn= |page=11 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref> There are a number of factors that can make a death be considered a tragedy.
===Scope=== The scope of an event can affect the public view, and make it appear tragic. This can be the case whether the death toll is high, or if a single, unexpected death occurs in a well-beloved person.<ref>{{cite book |title=Coping with public tragedy |last=Lattanzi-Licht |first=Marcia E. |authorlink= |author2=Kenneth J. Doka |publisher= |location= |isbn= |page=5 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref>
The degree of attachment in the public eye may also impact whether or not the event is publicly labeled as a tragedy. For example, the unexpected death of a [[University-preparatory school|preparatory school]] student that receives heavy media attention may be seen as more tragic than that of a [[recidivism|recidivist]] prisoner who is beaten to death by fellow inmates.<ref name=Lattanzi1 />
===Prematurity=== A death may be viewed as a tragedy when it is premature in nature. An old person dying of old age is an expectation, but the death of a child or of a young, healthy adult that is not expected by others can be viewed as tragic.<ref name=Lattanzi1/>
===Publicity=== [[Publicity]] is a factor in making the public view an event as a tragedy. With publicity of a large number of deaths or even a single death, this plays on the emotions of the general public, and thereby impacts perception.<ref>{{cite book |title=Coping with public tragedy |last=Lattanzi-Licht |first=Marcia E. |authorlink= |author2=Kenneth J. Doka |publisher= |location= |isbn= |page=3 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref>
The range of coverage affects the number of people in whose eyes the event is viewed as tragic. While local coverage may garner sympathy from those in the hometown of the deceased, international coverage may lead the whole world to mourn.<ref>{{cite book |title=Coping with public tragedy |last=Lattanzi-Licht |first=Marcia E. |authorlink= |author2=Kenneth J. Doka |publisher= |location= |isbn= |page=9 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref>
===Consequences=== The resulting consequences from one or more deaths can be seen as a tragedy. For example, if a large number of persons are killed in a terrorist attack, not only is life lost, but others may lose their sense of security, and this impacts the lives of others in other ways.<ref>{{cite book |title=Coping with public tragedy |last=Lattanzi-Licht |first=Marcia E. |authorlink= |author2=Kenneth J. Doka |publisher= |location= |isbn= |page=8 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref>
===Lasting effects=== The long-term effects of an event can render it as tragic. Tragedies often have effects that shape those affected, and are remembered even long after, as they clearly impact the future for those involved. They may also be commemorated on anniversaries or whenever they otherwise come to mind.<ref>Disaster Spiritual Care: Practical Clergy Responses to Community, Regional; by Stephen B. Roberts, Willard W. C. Ashley; {{ISBN|978-1-59473-240-9}}; page 67</ref> A public tragedy often leads to measures being taken to prevent similar tragic events in the future.<ref>{{cite book |title=Disaster Spiritual Care: Practical Clergy Responses to Community, Regional, and National Tragedy |last=Roberts |first=Stephen B. |authorlink= |author2=Willard W. C. Ashley |publisher= |location= |isbn=978-1-59473-240-9 |page=86 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref>
==Dealing with tragedy== There are various ways tragedy can affect people.
The typical reaction to tragedy is heavy [[grief]], followed by a slow recovery. Common feelings following a tragedy include [[sadness]], [[depression (mood)|depression]], [[crying]], [[blame]], and [[guilt (emotion)|guilt]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Tragedy: A psychiatrist offers ways to deal with trauma and grief |author=Alvin F. Poussaint, M.D. |newspaper=Ebony Magazine |date=February 1977 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AM4DAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA94&dq=coping+with+tragedy&hl=en&ei=jUT4TIfBFIWClAe0rvGgAw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=coping%20with%20tragedy&f=false |accessdate=}} </ref> Some people wonder what they did to deserve such suffering.<ref>{{cite book |title=Coping with Tragedy |last=Ramsey |first=Tara |authorlink= |publisher= |location= |isbn= |page=33 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref>
For some, their [[religion|faith]] may be a source of comfort in the wake of tragedy.<ref>{{cite book |title=Faith in the Fast Lane |last=Owens |first=Ken |authorlink= |publisher= |location= |isbn= |page=106 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Disaster]] *[[Collective trauma]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Grief]] [[Category:Events]]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=January 2013}}
{{Infobox chef <!-- for more information see [[:Template:Infobox chef/doc]] --> | image = | caption = | birth_name = Travis London | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|mf=y|1988|7|16}} | birth_place = Los Angeles, CA | death_date = | death_place = | style = | education = [[French Culinary Institute]] | spouse = | ratings = | restaurants = | website = [http://www.HealthyChicEats.com/ HealthyChicEats.com] }}
'''Travis London''' (born July 16, 1988) is an [[United States|American]] [[celebrity chef]], television host, writer, and event planner. He was born in [[Los Angeles]] and is of both Mexican and African American descent.
==Career== At 16, London began throwing parties for his friends, which eventually landed him on "Page Six" as a "party-going L.A. hipster". By the time he received formal training at the [[French Culinary Institute]], he had scored a food column in OK! Magazine and had prepared dishes for his celebrity friends Justin Timberlake, Mary-Kate Olsen, and former love interest Rihanna"<ref>{{cite news|url=http://uptownmagazine.com/2012/07/all-eyes-on-travis-london/|title=All Eyes On: Travis London|last=Campbell|first=Deena|date=July 5, 2012|accessdate=9 January 2013}}</ref>
Travis is the founder of Healthy Chic Eats, and regularly appears on the ''Today Show'', ''Fox and Friends'' and the ''Suzanne Somers Show''.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LJzO9to9lis|title=Suzanne Somers Cooking with Travis London|date=November 14, 2012|accessdate=9 January 2013}}</ref>
Travis has been profiled and quoted extensively in many periodicals, including ''[[OK! Magazine]]'',<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.okmagazine.com/news/celebrity-chef-travis-london-shares-his-guilt-free-vanilla-cupcake-recipe|title=Celebrity Chef Travis London Shares His Guilt-Free Vanilla Cupcake Recipe!|last=OK! Staff|date=March 23, 2011|publisher=[[OK! Magazine]]|accessdate=9 January 2013}}</ref> ''[[Us Weekly]]'',<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-style/pictures/beauty-buzz-o-meter-2011261/15300|title=THE US BUZZZZ-O-METER|last=UsWeekly|publisher=[[Us Weekly]]|accessdate=9 January 2013}}</ref> ''[[The New York Daily News]]'',<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/life-style/eats/celebrity-party-planner-travis-london-shakes-sexy-valentine-day-cocktails-article-1.1019883|title=Celebrity party planner Travis London shakes up sexy Valentine’s Day cocktails |last=Lee|first=Patty|date= February 11, 2012|publisher=[[The New York Daily News]]|accessdate=9 January 2013}}</ref> ''[[The Huffington Post]]'',<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/03/10/travis-london-celebrity-chef-sunday-brunch_n_1337058.html|title=Travis London, Celebrity Chef, At Sunday Brunch|last=Anderson|first=Jessica Cumberbatch|date=March 11, 2012|publisher=[[The Huffington Post]]|accessdate=9 January 2013}}</ref> ''The Sun Post Weekly'', ''Uptown Magazine'', ''[[Vibe (magazine)|Vibe]]'',<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.vibevixen.com/2012/09/4-delicious-cocktails-for-labor-day/2/|title=4 Delicious Cocktails for Labor Day|last=Edwards|first=Byron|date=September 3, 2012|publisher=[[Vibe (magazine)|Vibe]]|accessdate=9 January 2013}}</ref> ''[[Shape]]'',<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.shape.com/healthy-eating/healthy-drinks/16-low-cal-love-potions-valentines-day?page=8|title=16 Low-Cal Love Potions for Valentine's Day|last=Tse|first=Tiffany|date=February 14, 2012|publisher=[[Shape]]|accessdate=9 January 2013}}</ref> ''[[Latina]]'',<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.latina.com/food/recipes/brazilian-cocktail-recipe-x-rated-travis-london|title=Warning: This Cocktail is X-Rated!|last=Koday|first=Dan|date=March 29, 2012|publisher=[[Latina]]|accessdate=9 January 2013}}</ref> ''[[Cosmopolitan (magazine)|Cosmopolitan]]'',<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cosmopolitan.com/food/cocktails/neon-cocktails-x-rated-tangerine-touch#slide-3|title=16 Neon Cocktails You Have to Try|last=ADEEYO|first=DARA|publisher=[[Cosmopolitan (magazine)|Cosmopolitan]]|accessdate=9 January 2013}}</ref> ''Venue'', and the ''Miami Herald''.
Travis is a weekly contributor to ''[[OK! Magazine]]''<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.okmagazine.com/tag/travis-london|title=Travis London OK! Magazine Articles|last=OK! Staff|publisher=[[OK! Magazine]]|accessdate=9 January 2013}}</ref> and in 2012 was brand ambassador for [[X Rated Fusion Liqueur]].
==Cooking Influences== Growing up with a Georgia-bred African-American grandfather and Mexican maternal grandmother, Travis learned how to raise chickens, cook collard greens, and master homemade tamales.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.loop21.com/culture/travis-london-celebrity-chef|title=All Eyes on Celebrity Chef Travis London|last=Cabrera|first=Claudio Eduardo|accessdate=9 January 2013}}</ref> London credits his approach to eating healthy as being influenced by growing up with his mother being overweight. He has stated that at 13 he discovered healthy meals for his mother while watching Suzanne Somers on the Home Shopping Network.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://uptownmagazine.com/2012/07/all-eyes-on-travis-london/2/|title=All Eyes On: Travis London|last=Campbell|first=Deena|date=July 5, 2012|accessdate=9 January 2013}}</ref>
==Personal life== The media has noted several relationships with celebrities such as [[Rihanna]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/gossip/rihanna-stepping-travis-london-article-1.401643|title=Rihanna stepping out with Travis London in L.A.|last=Sidman|first=Amanda|date=September 6, 2009|publisher=[[The New York Daily News]]|accessdate=9 January 2013}}</ref> and [[Mary-Kate Olsen]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.popsugar.com/MKs-Mystery-Man-Revealed-94596|title=MK's Mystery Man Revealed|last=PopSugar|date=December 29, 2006|publisher=[[PopSugar]]|accessdate=9 January 2013}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.healthychiceats.com/website/ Healthy Chic Eats]
{{DEFAULTSORT:London, Travis}} [[Category:1988 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Writers from Los Angeles]] [[Category:American chefs]] [[Category:Male chefs]] [[Category:American food writers]] [[Category:American people of Mexican descent]] [[Category:International Culinary Center alumni]] [[Category:Event planners]] [[Category:African-American chefs]]

page.title: Types of fiction with multiple endings

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=February 2018}}
'''Multiple endings''' refer to a case in entertainment where the story could end in different ways.
==Comics== * ''[[The Death-Ray]]'' by [[Daniel Clowes]]. * ''[[Cliff Hanger (comic strip)|Cliff Hanger]]''.<ref> by [[Jack Edward Oliver]]. {{cite book|last=Oliver|first=Jack Edward|title=Buster|date=25 June 1983|publisher=Fleetway}}</ref>
==Literature== * The ''[[Choose Your Own Adventure]]'' series. * ''[[Life's Lottery]]''
==Theater==
*[[Ayn Rand]]'s 1934 play ''[[Night of January 16th]]'' allowed the audience to affect the ending by acting as the "jury" and voting the defendant "innocent" or "guilty".<ref>{{cite book |ref=harv |title=[[The Passion of Ayn Rand]] |last=Branden |first=Barbara |authorlink=Barbara Branden |location=Garden City, New York |publisher=Doubleday & Company |year=1986 |isbn=0-385-19171-5 |oclc=12614728 |pages=122–124}}</ref> *The 1985 musical ''[[The Mystery of Edwin Drood (musical)|The Mystery of Edwin Drood]]''. *[[Dario Fo]]'s 1970 play, ''[[Accidental Death of an Anarchist]]''. *The long-running play ''[[Shear Madness]]'' has multiple, audience-selected endings
==Films== DVDs may include an [[alternate ending]] as a special feature. These are usually not considered [[canon (fiction)|canon]].

{{Howto|date=December 2014}} '''Unintentional discharge''' is the event of a [[firearm]] discharging (firing) at a time not intended by the user. An unintended discharge may be produced by an incompatibility between firearm design and usage, such as the phenomenon of [[cooking off]] a round in a closed bolt machine gun, a mechanical malfunction as in the case of [[slamfire]] in an automatic weapon, user induced due to training issues or negligence, or a simple accident. The phenomenon has also been defined in the scientific literature as ''an activation of the trigger mechanism that results in an unplanned discharge that is outside of the firearm’s prescribed use''. Where prescribed use refers to departmental policies and laws related to the operation of firearms (O'Neill, 2018).
==Accidental discharge==
An '''accidental discharge''' ('''AD''') may occur when the trigger of the firearm is deliberately pulled for a purpose other than shooting—dry-fire practice, demonstration, or function testing—but ammunition is unintentionally left in the chamber. Unintentionally leaving a firearm loaded is more likely to occur when the individual handling the gun is poorly trained, and perhaps also with removable-magazine-fed firearms (as the magazine may be removed, giving an unloaded appearance even when a round remains chambered—see discussion of magazine-safeties below).
A second common cause of negligent discharges is when the gun-handler places their finger on the trigger before they have decided to shoot. With the finger so positioned, many activities may cause the finger to compress the trigger unintentionally. For example, if one attempts to holster the firearm with finger on trigger, the holster edge will drive the finger onto the trigger, and discharge is likely. If one stumbles or struggles (with an adversary) with finger on trigger, the grasping motion of both hands will likely cause the trigger finger to compress the trigger.
[[Gun safety]] rules recognize the above possibilities, and aim to prevent them. The primary firearm safety rule usually listed by any source is a version of "Always keep the gun pointed in safe direction."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Izak|first1=Shultz|title=Gun Safe Reviews|url=http://www.shootingandsafety.com/best-gun-safe-reviews/|website=Shooting & Safety|accessdate=23 February 2017|date=26 August 2015}}</ref> Following this rule ensures that, should an accidental discharge occur, no harm will be done. Second, one's finger should remain outside the trigger guard until the decision has been made to fire the weapon; even if (some would say especially if) one is facing a hostile adversary and has to be prepared to fire at a moment's notice, keeping the finger out of the trigger-guard until one has decided to shoot will prevent an accidental shooting.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.backwoodshome.com/articles2/ayoob103.html|title=The subtleties of safe firearms handling|last=Ayoob|first=Massad|date=February 2007|website=Issue #103|publisher=Backwoods Home Magazine|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
When a firearm is not in use, storing it unloaded and in a separate container from ammunition may also help prevent accidental discharges, especially if the stored firearm is "accessed" by an unauthorized user.
On occasion, an accidental discharge can occur by means other than the finger pulling the [[trigger (firearms)|trigger]], such as dropping a loaded weapon. Because of this possibility, most currently produced pistols are designed with a "drop-safety" or [[Safety (firearms)#Firing pin block|firing pin block]], a mechanism inhibiting or isolating the firing pin, preventing accidental discharge if the firearm is dropped. However, most long guns do not have drop-safeties.
Prevention of dropped-firearm ADs with long guns therefore depends on the user being familiar with the precautions needed for that particular gun: it is standard practice for all long-gun users to unload the firearm's chamber before any activity that might foreseeably result in a dropped firearm (e.g., climbing a fence while hunting), and before placing the firearm in a vehicle (where sudden deceleration may cause the firearm to act as if dropped).
Accidental discharges not involving trigger-pull can also occur if the firearm is mechanically unsound: poor maintenance, abuse, inept "gunsmithing," or the use of substandard materials or defective [[ammunition]] in the gun may all lead to breakage.
In World War II, early versions of the British [[Sten gun]] were notorious for accidentally discharging when dropped. While dropping any long gun with loaded chamber can be dangerous, the use of a soft bronze bolt in early Stens—allowing the [[Sear (firearm)|sear]] contact area to wear down quickly—made ADs even more likely.
As the early Sten gun illustrates, "poor design," including the specification of unsuitable component materials, is sometimes cited as a cause for some firearms being "unsafe." Surely, any firearm that can discharge by itself when loaded is unsafe, and no user would want to handle a firearm that has a high likelihood of accidental discharge when employed for its intended use. But, firearm designs incorporating fewer safeties are not intrinsically unsafe—see discussion of long-guns above—even if they do require competence and proper training for safe use.
A relevant discussion attends the use of [[Safety (firearms)#Magazine Interlocks|magazine-safeties]] in semi-automatic pistols. Such safeties prevent the pistol from firing if there is a round in the chamber, but the magazine is removed. Some self-defense experts dislike this feature, as it may allow the pistol to be "disabled" unexpectedly during a struggle, so that the pistol fails when needed. Others feel that it may improve user safety and prevent some accidental discharges. Both semi-auto pistol designs, with and without magazine-safeties, are currently manufactured.
One last form of accidental discharge, known as ''[[cooking off]],'' occurs when a weapon becomes overheated, with the firing chamber hot enough to ignite the propellant charge in the ammunition round, causing the cartridge to fire. As recently as 1979, this problem doomed the innovative [[Heckler & Koch G11]] during NATO trials.
"Cooking off" is typically encountered only in [[fully automatic]] weapons, such as [[machine gun]]s, when they are fired for long periods of time without allowing the barrel and chamber of the weapon to cool down to safe temperatures. For this reason, modern crew-served machine guns are equipped with spare [[Gun barrel|barrel]]s to allow a machine gun crew to replace an overheated barrel with a cool one, thus restoring the weapon to action while the overheated barrel is allowed to cool. Also, the majority of machine guns fire from an [[open bolt]], so the round is chambered only after pressing the trigger, just before firing.
==Negligent discharge==
A '''negligent discharge''' ('''ND''') is a discharge of a [[firearm]] involving [[Culpability|culpable]] carelessness. In judicial and military technical terms, a negligent discharge is a chargeable offence. A number of [[armed force]]s automatically consider any [[accidental discharge]] to be negligent discharge, under the assumption that a trained soldier has control of his firearm at all times. This is the case in the [[United States Army]],<ref>Trevino, Abel. "Proper Weapons Practices Key to Ending Negligent Discharge Incidents in Iraq." ''army.mil''. United States Army. 1 March 2007. [http://www.army.mil/-news/2007/03/01/2065-proper-weapons-practices-key-to-ending-negligent-discharge-incidents-in-iraq/]</ref> [[Canadian Army]], the [[Royal Air Force]], the [[British Army]] and various Police Forces within the United Kingdom.
From an article on a U.S. Air Force website: {{quote|A negligent discharge occurs when a weapon is fired due to either operator error or a lack of attention to basic safety rules.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.jber.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123376171 | title=Negligent discharge: Don’t be that guy | publisher=Joint Base Elmendorf-Richardson, USAF | date=9 January 2014 | accessdate=18 December 2014 | author=Cunningham, Vernon}}</ref>}}
